PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Ownership
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned notes that the level of foreign ownership and control of Australian assets is of concern to many Australians.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should introduce legislation to:
(a) establish a register of foreign ownership.
(b) limit foreign ownership of real estate.
(c) control foreign investment in Australia so as to protect the national interest.
(d) increase the powers and resources of the Foreign Investment Review Board.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
This Petition of concerned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
The basic pension is already below the poverty line and imposing any reduction to the pension or levies for medications will cause widespread suffering and sickness.
A charge on medications will represent a callous repudiation of the promise to establish and maintain the pension at 25% of Average Weekly Wage.
The rumoured abolition of the invalid pension has caused untold worry and heartbreak among the afflicted on that benefit.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should introduce legislation to:

Quickly raise the pension to 30% AWE; restore medications removed from the free list and there be no charge on medicine; the invalid pension be retained; and the harassment of pensioners through `kite flying' rumours cease immediately.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Powell) and pursuant to contingent notice I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Powell moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely, a motion to give precedence to General Business notice of motion No. 71 standing in the name of Senator Spindler, relating to the distribution of wealth in Australia.

It is essential that we suspend Standing Orders. At the moment there is a growing disparity of wealth in Australia. We all know the social consequences of such a trend. In fact, we have a social justice policy and strategy put forward by the Government but we are not using the tools. The Australian Bureau of Statistics is a very efficient organisation but its resources are not used. We need-and it is indeed urgent-to suspend Standing Orders to consider having an inquiry into the distribution of wealth and to develop strategies that will lead to the alleviation of the detrimental social conditions which result from the current disparity of wealth in Australia.

I refer in particular to the various taxation matters which are both a result and a cause of such disparity of wealth. We are looking at the fact that capital gains are taxed on a real basis whereas the tax on income is based on the nominal income received, that a principal residence is exempt from capital gains tax, that most life insurance policies extending for more than 10 years are exempt from income tax, and that some holding costs of assets qualify for concessional tax treatment. I refer to negative gearing. All of those matters relate to how wealth is acquired in our community.

I express some disappointment at both the Opposition parties and the Government not wishing to know. Ignorance in this matter is not bliss. We should suspend Standing Orders so that we can discuss, investigate and initiate an inquiry into wealth distribution in Australia so that we can develop a strategy for social justice. The Government professes support and the Opposition often uses words of support but no deeds are seen because they are not interested.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. Senator Spindler is not speaking to the motion that General Business notice of motion No. 71 be given priority. In fact he is canvassing other subjects. I ask that he be brought to order.

—Mr Deputy President, on the point of order: we are now under new procedures in which an honourable senator is given only five minutes to argue for the suspension of Standing Orders. This was brought in almost exclusively to allow someone five minutes to traverse a bit of ground. I think it does impinge on Standing Orders a bit. But it was done so that we would not put the President or the Deputy President in the position of having constantly to answer 20 points of order in a row about relevance. For the guidance of the Senate, I suggest that people be given a bit of scope now that they are limited to speaking for five minutes as opposed to a half hour wander that previously existed.

—I had been listening to Senator Spindler carefully. With the knowledge that he had only five minutes to speak, I was not prepared to mention relevance, although Senator Spindler is aware of it. Senator Spindler, I call you for the rest of your time.

—I appreciate the indulgence of the Senate. I was developing the argument as to why we should suspend Standing Orders and why it was urgent that we do so. I believe it is incumbent upon the members of this Senate to ensure that social justice is done in this country. We should be using as a matter of urgency the measures that are available to us. We should have an inquiry that should extend over two years, that should have four or five commissioners, that should use the resources of the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) and that should also incorporate the work of the social policy research centre of the University of New South Wales and the work done by Dr Peter Saunders and Professor John Neville at that university. The work that is being done by the ABS and by the University of New South Wales will not be effective unless we have a goal directed inquiry. I therefore put it to the Senate that it is urgent that we suspend Standing Orders to enable that strategy to be instituted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

SPEECH.PARA: I might inform Senator Spindler that we have this quaint procedure in the Senate of devoting a certain time of the week in most weeks to private business. The Australian Democrats always get one session at that time. I admit it is not a lot of time. But let us see how important this issue is. Senator Spindler had to say why it was urgent that we suspend Standing Orders today. It was purely out of political opportunism so that he could get some votes. I do not see why the Senate, in which all of us are also chasing votes, should be facilitating this matter today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a matter of considerable urgency. It is very convenient for the members of the Senate in their very comfortable positions and with their nice salaries to regard the matter of the growing disparity between the rich and the poor in this country as not a matter of urgency. It is indeed a matter of great urgency for those people who are suffering in the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that this motion in substantially the same form was moved by colleagues of the senators sitting on the Labor benches; that was Mr Barry Jones and Mr Duncan Kerr. In their joint press release I draw Senator Robert Ray's attention to the fact that they specifically point out that the last significant survey of wealth in Australia was in the late 1960s-more than 20 years ago.

As Senator Spindler has pointed out, the members of this chamber evidently do not want to know. We have seen this repeatedly in other cases of simply collecting data which would indicate where this country is going and honourable senators on both the Labor side and on the Opposition benches have voted against collecting information. I draw the Senate's attention to our repeated calls for the investigation of the degree of foreign ownership, which bears very much on this question of wealth distribution.

Again I point out that the Labor colleagues of the honourable senators who sit on my left-it is rather unusual that they are sitting on my left at the moment-in their press release pointed out that the wealthiest 10 per cent of the population hold 55.2 per cent of the wealth of the country, and the degree of disparity is growing.

This is indeed a matter of considerable urgency, a matter to which the Senate should be bending its mind now. We should not be endlessly putting off consideration of this very important matter. It lies at the very heart of a fair, just and equitable society-a society which to some extent Australia possessed in years past. That is a society and a model from which we are progressively moving under a so-called Labor government-I stress, a so-called Labor government-which is moving away from the policies on which it was elected, the policies for which the Australian people voted at the last election. We are seeing this in relation to privatisation, the opening up of more uranium mines and a whole lot of other issues on which the Government is not observing the very policies for which it was elected.

I would have thought that one of the most fundamental planks upon which the Australian Labor Party was elected was the plank of equity. This motion goes to the heart of that matter. We are becoming a less equitable society and it is indeed a matter of urgency that we debate this matter now and collect the data on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill that was presented to us, which we agreed to, is designed to deregulate the airline industry and give an opportunity for more airlines to participate in the commercial airline structure in Australia. I am wondering whether the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) could tell us which airports of the major cities-the six capitals, the national capital and Darwin-have space available in the existing terminals for lease to any new airlines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Reid's important question, the matter of access to gate facilities is essential if deregulation is to succeed. The question of access to gates is not a problem. I have said many times in this debate that comparisons of Australian deregulation with deregulation that has occurred in countries overseas are fraught with danger.

SPEECH.PARA: We need to ensure that when we are talking about deregulation and the effects of it, we relate it strictly to the realities of the Australian aviation market. For that reason I predicted, prior to the announcement on priorities on gate access, that there was not going to be an avalanche of new contenders rushing to the barricades to start new airlines, as there was in the United States, the reason being, as I have said before, that in terms of the realities of our aviation market, we are a tiny player internationally.

We have a country the size of the United States, with a transport task the size of that of the United States and with a population the size of the city of Los Angeles. One American airline has 10 times the number of jet aircraft that our total combined jet aircraft operations have. So the costs of getting into the aviation industry and the overheads are enormous. They place real restrictions on the availability of slots in the market.

I was attacked by some of the players in that game when I was simply telling the truth. The reality in fact is precisely that. Only one airline-that is, Compass-has indicated that it is in a position in the short term, and I am talking about the next 12 months, to effectively begin airline operations in a deregulated market. It is in fact in a very firm position to do so.

I am happy to take this opportunity to advise the Senate that I had a meeting with Mr Grey last week, simply to be brought up to date on where his airline is at. He is well advanced, with staff fully employed, with aircraft in hand. He is in the last stages, in fact, of negotiating the gate access, to which Senator Reid has just referred, with Australian Airlines Ltd and is in a position to begin his operations on schedule later this year. But he is the only operator to be in a position to do so.

In addition to the gate access Federal Airports Corporation is providing already at Brisbane, Sydney, Perth, Melbourne, Adelaide and Launceston-and I have given this information to the Senate previously-it has given an absolute guarantee that if that is not sufficient, and I can tell the Senate at this point in time that it is more than sufficient, it will immediately move to provide whatever additional gate access is required to ensure that whatever viable operators are in a position to start, the one barrier that will not prevent them from doing so is access to terminal facilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Taking Sydney, for example, the Minister says a new operator can negotiate with Australian Airlines Ltd. How many gateways are vacant at present, to be leased directly to a new operator, in the same way as gateways are leased to Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Two gates have been freed up at the airport and can be negotiated. As I said, I have given a detailed explanation of this to the Senate before. I am happy to provide Senator Reid-I will organise it right now-with a printed copy of the priorities that I advised the Senate of, the number of gates at each airport and the airlines from 1 to 7 that were given priorities to those gates.

SPEECH.PARA: I just say again, gate access is not a problem. There is only one operator currently negotiating for gates. Interestingly enough, the only complaint that I have received as Minister is not from an entrant wanting to get into the gates but a bit of a grizzle from one of the airlines that the only entrant about to start operating in a deregulated market is talking to one operator rather than the other. So there is simply no problem.

If Senator Reid has information that a prospective entrant is in a position to begin airline operations-and that, of course, is the condition the Government has placed on this-it has to demonstrate that it can provide a service. If more gates are to be freed up, I would be very anxious to hear from Senator Reid, but the reality is that Compass Airlines at the moment is it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) thinks I am pursuing something that I am not. I just want to know the facts. We have two entrances at Canberra Airport. As I understand it, they are both currently leased to airlines which are operating. Why are there not arrangements in place? Why cannot another airline have access arrangements through a lease similar to those which exist? Why do other airlines have to go crawling to an existing airline to get access to an airport? They are extremely disadvantaged in doing so by the Government's action in trying to thwart deregulation by getting rid of the airports as fast as it could before this legislation was brought into existence. It seems to me that prospective entrants considering coming in would know that they have a battle on their hands to get access to the terminals. I am not suggesting that there are any other players around; in fact, it is not surprising that there are not when one looks at how difficult it is to get access in Sydney, which is the main gateway to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Canberra Airport is very small and perhaps of little concern to the Government. There are just two entrances and, as I understand it, both are currently leased to existing airlines which have no interest whatever in being generous to any competitor coming in. What arrangements is the Government making to ensure that it is in a position to lease space to a competitor and not merely tell a competitor that he can go off and see how well he can do with either Ansett Airlines of Australia or Australian Airlines, both of whom may have an interest in making life as difficult as possible for any competitor? The same thing applies to landing rights at Sydney. Will they be carved up easily so that people can have a fair share?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Reid's statement is absolute and utter nonsense. Frankly, I thought she would have known that. It is about time this nonsense was nailed down. I say to Senator Reid again that if she can provide me with information on one single operator who is even expressing an interest-and I put it as mildly as that-in getting gate access at an airport and cannot get gate access, I would like to hear from him.
—You are avoiding the question.

—I will proceed across the non-stop interjections of the aviation expert on the front bench opposite. She demonstrated her total lack of expertise on a committee I served on in the not too distant past. The fact is that there is no barrier to a new entrant being provided at the moment with gate access. The airlines are required to negotiate on a bona fide basis with new entrants. They cannot negotiate extortionate demands, they are only able to negotiate on a bona fide basis. At the end of the day if they cannot achieve that arrangement, then the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) is in a position to intrude at that point.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from the nonsense that Senator Reid is asserting in the chamber today about this being a barrier, I am able to negotiate and to speak with the actual entrants who are in a position to be negotiating with these airlines. They are not having extortionate demands placed on them.

In regard to Canberra Airport, I say to Senator Reid quite precisely that I have the details with me. I am happy to table this information in the Senate again. It has been tabled once before and Senator Reid can refer to it simply by going to the Table Office. If she wants this debate held up again with that sort of detail, having gone over it already in the chamber, I am happy to do it.

To get to the very point of Senator Reid's question, I repeat: nobody is being faced with extortionate demands from the existing airlines. These valuable assets have to be negotiated in a bona fide commercial manner. As I have said before, the cost of getting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Which you gave them undisputed right to with your lease.

—What a load of nonsense. That indicates again the extent of ignorance on the Opposition benches. Is Senator Newman seriously saying to me that gate access at the busiest international and national terminal in Australia should be traded off at a bargain basement price by anybody, or that it would be by the FAC? The FAC is in a position to make those airports pay. That is its charter. If it had the total right-not Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines-it would be negotiating with new entrants on the same commercial basis as Ansett and Australian are currently doing. No extortionate demands are being made. I might say that that view is from the company which is currently in a position of carrying out the only negotiations in process.

SPEECH.PARA: Rather than talking about the hypothetical nonsense that Senator Reid has been talking about, let me state the facts. The gate access that is being negotiated at the moment is being successfully concluded. If it cannot be, at the end of the day the FAC will intrude and ensure that it is. That provision already exists. If any operator wants to operate out of Canberra-I can tell Senator Reid that so far none have been forthcoming-the FAC has given an absolute commitment that gate access will be provided either from the existing lessees or from the construction of brand new facilities by the FAC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer was most interesting in dealing with matters that I did not put to the Committee but which the Minister is obviously extremely sensitive about. His sensitivity and near-hysteria in answering the question give me certain reason to be concerned for the future that what I am suggesting may well be true.

—I ask the Minister precisely how a new entrant will have the opportunity to have adequate space at Launceston Airport, for example. I am not talking about a dunny or a caravan in the car park; I am talking about facilities in the terminal. Not only has it just been leased by the Government on the eve of the Federal Airports Corporation coming into being, in a very shonky and shady manner in my view, but also only in the last few weeks the terminal has been so subdivided by security facilities that I cannot see how a new entrant can come into the existing terminal. In the meantime, is it expected to camp in the car park as did a previous one which went broke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply say again in this tired old debate, based on hypothesism and not fact, that if either of the honourable senators contributing to this debate-and I am anxious to communicate with them-know of any operator who is currently in a position of difficulty in getting either actual facilities or prospective facilities, they should let me hear of it, because no-one has been to see me.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 17, page 8, lines 26 to 29, leave out subclause 4.

The purpose of these amendments is to withdraw the two clauses in the Australian National Maritime Museum Bill which apply age discrimination. Subclause 17 (4) provides that a person who has attained the age of 65 years shall not be appointed as a member of the council of the Australian Maritime Museum nor will a person be appointed for a term which takes him beyond the age of 65 years as a member of that council. Subclause 30 (2) provides that, in similar circumstances, a person may not be appointed a director of the Australian National Maritime Museum. In other words, a person who has attained the age of 65 years cannot be appointed director nor can a person be appointed as director for a term which will extend beyond his reaching the age of 65 years.

Both of these clauses are a blatant example of age discrimination. The Opposition is most strongly opposed to this form of discrimination. Our amendments simply remove both of those subclauses and therefore remove the age discrimination aspects contained in this legislation.

If the Senate agrees to our amendments, this Bill will be brought into line with the Public Service Act. The Public Service Act, as amended, now allows public servants to stay on in their jobs beyond the age of 65 years. In particular, division 8a of the Public Service Act provides for secretaries to departments to remain beyond the age of 65 years at the discretion of the relevant authority. Of course, the Secretary to a department can be equated to the position of director to this museum. There is now a specific provision in the Public Service Act which allows secretaries to departments to remain in their positions beyond the age of 65 years. Quite clearly, the same provision should apply to the director of this museum.

Division 8b of the Public Service Act allows a similar discretion for senior executive officers of the Public Service to remain in the office beyond the age of 65 years. Division 8c provides the same opportunity for other officers of government departments.

Section 33 of the Public Service Act, which relates to the application of the merit principle, provides that there should be no discrimination in the Public Service on the grounds of age. Furthermore, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission regulations provide that it is an offence to discriminate on the grounds of age and that such offences may be heard by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commissioner.

It should also be noted that this legislation provides in clause 40 that the provisions of the Public Service Act will apply to the staff of the Museum. On the one hand we see in this legislation a provision that the staff of the Museum may remain in their jobs working beyond the age of 65 years; yet under the same legislation, unless our amendments are accepted, the Director and members of the Council, whose purpose it is to advise the Director and to advise the Government generally on the operation of this Museum, will not be able to remain in those positions beyond the age of 65 years-a complete absurdity with regard to the way in which this legislation has been drafted.

With regard to the Council, the very people whom we may want to appoint, because of the experience and expertise they have, may well be over the age of 65, as was mentioned in the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts discussion on this legislation. For instance, retired sea captains or people of that ilk, who have specific experience that would be relevant to the operation of the Australian National Maritime Museum, would be people of great quality on a council of this type and yet they will be precluded unless this legislation is amended.

The Minister, Senator Richardson, indicated in the Standing Committee hearing that the Government would not accept our amendments because it wanted to review the issue of age discrimination in toto. In fact, the Government wanted to review all of the Acts of this Parliament that apply age discrimination and subsequently introduce a blanket amendment that may remove that age discrimination. We really could not get any definite commitment from the Minister that this was to happen. He seemed to have some view that public opinion needed to be obtained before the Government would be prepared to move forward and remove age discrimination from Government legislation.

Surely the public is only too well aware of the negative aspects of age discrimination and is only too convinced of the need to remove age discrimination as it is of the need to remove all other forms of discrimination in our society. The public does not need this Government to go out and try to market a policy to remove age discrimination before it can proceed. That opposition to age discrimination in this day and age is well established in the community and there is absolutely no need for the Government to do that.

There is also no need for the Government to leave this absurdity in this legislation on the basis that it wants to amend all legislation to remove age discrimination at some future indeterminate date. When we have legislation before us that is faulty, we should fix it up when it is here and not allow it to be passed in this chamber in a form which even the Government admits is faulty. We should fix up the legislation here and now when we have the opportunity. If the Government wishes to take other measures in the future on a global basis, let it do that. But let us fix up this legislation while we have the opportunity to do so.

In the Standing Committee's consideration of the Bill, the Minister made a number of contradictory remarks. He indicated at the outset that the Government would be speedily moving to amend all legislation that had age discrimination inherent in it, but later he could not give any guarantee that the Government was to move forward at all on this issue and certainly could not give us any guarantee that it would happen speedily. He indicated that the issue had been referred to the Attorney-General's Department and was the subject of an inquiry and he expected to have a report on that shortly. However, later in his remarks the Minister indicated, in answer to a question from Senator Bourne, that because one of the concerns of the Government was that Comcare legislation as currently drafted did not provide cover for people beyond the age of 65, legislation to change the Comcare arrangements would be one of the first issues addressed-one of the first pieces of amending legislation brought into this chamber to remove age discrimination.

In the Estimates Committee hearings of the Department of Industrial Relations last week, I questioned Comcare about this issue. In response its representatives indicated they were aware that some inquiry was going on with regard to age discrimination in the Attorney-General's Department but they had not been asked to give any consideration to changing Comcare legislation. They had not given any detailed consideration to the issue of providing Comcare cover beyond the age of 65. They had not been asked to draft any legislation with regard to age discrimination. Nothing is happening within Comcare to get rid of age discrimination and to solve the alleged problems with regard to Comcare and age discrimination.

The Minister's indication that we will be able to solve this problem relatively quickly and that Comcare legislation will be the first dealt with in this area is simply contradicted by the evidence given at that Estimates Committee. We will be waiting for an indeterminate and lengthy time before anything is done about age discrimination. The Australian Democrats should recognise that. We are still not guaranteed that anything will happen, but if it does it will be some distant time down the track before we get a satisfactory resolution to this problem. From the Opposition's point of view that is completely unsatisfactory and unacceptable. This legislation before us now, which incorporates age discrimination, should be fixed up now while we have the chance to do so and we should not wait for some indeterminate action of the Government down the track.

The issue of Comcare is not really an issue because already the Public Service Act provides that people can remain in the employ of the Public Service beyond the age of 65 and, therefore, they are already not covered by Comcare. Public servants would represent a significantly large group. In this legislation we are only dealing with a few people: the Council and the Director of the Museum. To add them to the people for whom other arrangements would have to be made for compensation is a minimal requirement on this Government and is not an excuse for rejecting our amendments and further delaying the reform of age discrimination.

With those remarks I conclude. I hope that the Democrats will see fit to support us on this occasion, contrary to the view they adopted in the Standing Committee. For that reason we have brought back this issue for debate in the Committee of the Whole. It was clear from looking at the Minister's remarks that they were contradictory. His comments with regard to Comcare were not accurate and, therefore, the Opposition's amendment ought to be supported in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is today dealing with the Customs (Detention and Search) Bill 1990 which has previously passed through the House of Representatives. Since it passed through the other House some members of the Senate have received a letter from the Law Council of Australia, expressing some concerns that the Council now seems to have regarding technical aspects. So this seems quite an appropriate piece of legislation to be dealt with by the new procedures we have been discussing so fervently this morning. I am glad that it is proposed that the Customs (Detention and Search) Bill will be going off to a legislative and standing committee for further scrutiny.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, the Opposition is conscious that a person's human rights and the need to balance these against the protection of the community have both been taken into account in considering this Bill. It is very, very important to all of us that the growing importation of illegal goods-drugs, narcotics and even weapons-be stemmed. All these things pose a threat to our society and that was of the utmost concern in the Opposition's consideration of the Bill.

We all know only too well that drugs especially are an increasing problem in our society. The number of people using drugs is increasing each year and the ages of those using them are getting lower. No special group seems to be isolated from drug usage, even amongst those with whom I have a particular interest-that is, the defence personnel. They too have an increasing number of members using drugs. Once again, the difficulty of identifying them is very important, particularly if the safety of other members of a military team is going to be prejudiced by those under the influence of drugs. It is clear that it is vitally important to the Defence Force.

According to a 1985 survey, 25 per cent of the general population have used illegal drugs at some time in their life. But this had risen to 28 per cent in a similar survey conducted only three years later, in 1988. That 1988 survey showed that males in the 20 to 39 year age bracket were the strongest users of drugs; 15 per cent of that population had for a consistent period used drugs; 8 per cent of males used amphetamines, 5 per cent used heroin and cocaine, while the remaining 2 per cent were users of other drugs, including LSD.
In that study in 1988 it was also found that cannabis is regularly used by 10 per cent of all school students, 3 per cent of all students illicitly used sedatives, while 2 per cent used amphetamines.

Similarly alarming are the numbers of drug-related deaths. In 1987 some 25,300 deaths in Australia were directly caused by drugs; whether it was overdoses, AIDS-related caused by using infected needles, or accidents resulting from drug usage. The National Drug Abuse Information Centre suggests that one in every three deaths in the 15 to 34 year age group is drug-related.

If ever there was an indictment of a society, those figures surely tell the tale. Therefore, anything that we as the legislative body in this country can do to stem the tide of drugs coming into our country should surely be done.

These facts and figures have been foremost in the minds of members of the Opposition when we approached this piece of legislation. Those figures have had to be in our minds in weighing up what have to be acknowledged as infringements of human rights once this Bill is passed. One has to weigh up the relative merits of two undesirable matters-on the one hand, the effect of drugs on our society and, on the other, the restriction of human rights in order to stem the flow.

But methods for the importation and concealment of drugs have become increasingly sophisticated. Thus it is appropriate that the Australian Customs Service improve its methods both of detection and of recovery. Drug trafficking is not selective. Drugs have been found on a 63-year-old priest, on a grandmother, and some parents have even had their babies or children carry drugs into this country. A person from Thailand was arrested carrying 93 condoms containing 700 grams of heroin internally.

The new Bill will give the Australian Customs Service more comprehensive powers to detain and search passengers and incoming visitors suspected of carrying illegal goods or drugs. I just draw attention to the matters that were identified in the second reading speech of the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray). The Minister said that in 1988-89 the total number of persons searched was 2,505 which represented 0.06 per cent of the total arriving passenger population of 4.2 million. Of this number of searches, 102 persons were detained for internal search and in most cases those persons consented to X-ray by a medical practitioner. The Minister stated that the figures clearly show that the present power is exercised in a judicious and controlled way and it is not expected by the Government that as a result of this Bill the number of persons searched should show any marked increase. We hope that, as a result of this legislation, the human rights elements might be improved.

The Bill provides for three levels of search: a frisk search, an external search and an internal search. The Opposition was very keen to ensure that each of these levels becomes more thorough and that controls placed on the Customs officers were also strengthened. Customs officers currently only have the power to conduct an internal or an external search. These searches must be ordered by a justice of the peace or the Comptroller-General of Customs. The order must be based on the reasonable suspicion of the Customs officer leading him or her to believe that the person is carrying illegal drugs. All searches conducted must be done by an officer of the same sex and, in the case of an internal search, by a medical practitioner.

The current system is inadequate in terms of the protection it offers both to the civil liberties and to the privacy of the traveller. The current system does not provide, for example, for a search to be carried out in private. Nor does it allow any protection for those who do not speak English. We know that the numbers of non-English travellers entering Australia are very high. Surprisingly, the current legislation does not provide the detainee with the right to a lawyer. Bearing all this in mind, it is of some concern that the Customs Office has had this legislation on the backburner for so long.

The new legislation enables the frisk search to be implemented. Basically this is similar to that which all senators have had experience of every time they go through security checks at airports around the world, with a quick running of the hands over the person's outer garments and anything voluntarily removed by that person. This search is restricted to officers of Customs and where that officer suspects on reasonable grounds that the person is carrying illegal goods. The Opposition is pleased to note that the invasion of the detainee's privacy has been minimised by the right of the detainee to have the frisk search conducted in private if he desires.

Moving to the second level of search, the external search, this is slightly more intrusive than the frisk. An external search is a search of the body and anything worn by a person to determine whether the person is carrying prohibited goods. The external search can only be undertaken if ordered by a justice of the peace, the Customs Comptroller-General or an officer of supervisory rank. Suspicions of the Customs officer must be strong enough to warrant a search being required. As with the frisk search, this may be undertaken in private and must be by an officer of the same sex.

The third level of search, and the most intrusive, is the internal search. This level of search is the one which is most thought to invade personal privacy. The Opposition was very concerned to ensure that any invasion of personal privacy was minimised and that regulations on Australian Customs Service officers were controlled. An internal search can only be undertaken where a person is suspected of carrying illegal narcotics in a commercial or trafficable quantity. This is opposed to carrying illegal goods, which is the test applied to the previous two levels of search.

If the detainee does not consent to the search, it can only proceed following two periods of 48-hour detention to allow any substances being carried to be emitted naturally. Both the period of detention and the search have to be individually ordered by a magistrate or a judge. The judge must give due weight to all evidence, including new or emerging facts.

A detainee held for an internal search has a right to a lawyer to be present or to represent him at the hearings seeking the detention and search orders. An internal search is to be conducted by a medical practitioner at a hospital.

Medical practitioners are provided for in the legislation in terms of any suit which may arise as a result of the search, with the exception of negligence. If the detainee is a minor or is mentally or physically incapacitated, he has a right to protection at all three levels of search.

I understand from the shadow Minister for Customs in the other place, that the Customs Office has reached agreement with the States regarding the provision and compensation of the judiciary. I also understand that it has reached a similar agreement regarding the provision of medical practitioners.

The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, which looked into the human rights aspects of the legislation, regarded the rights of the individual as adequately protected. The Committee also considered that appropriate efforts had been made to protect persons against abuses of power by Customs and police officers.

The Opposition supports the legislation as we understand it to affect the rights of individuals. But as I stated when I began my speech, we have some concerns which relate to the matters that have been recently raised by the Law Council of Australia. On the whole, we believe that the invasion of privacy has been adequately balanced against giving the community sufficient protection from traffickers of illegal drugs and narcotic substances. We should be looking at this legislation in the light of a response by the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) to the report of the parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority which was tabled on 6 June, entitled Drugs, Crime and Society. The Attorney-General has responded to that report. In his response he stated:

The Government takes this opportunity to reaffirm its ongoing commitment to the policy underlying the National Campaign against Drug Abuse, which is that Australia requires a balanced mix of strategies which will both reduce the demand for drugs-primarily by preventing drug use before it starts-as well as reduce their supply.
We believe that the Bill before the Senate today will help to reduce the demand for drugs, as well as do it in a way which is fair to the individuals who may well be affected.

With regard to the concerns of the Law Council of Australia, the Opposition has taken the trouble to put these concerns before the Customs Service and has then discussed the responses of the Customs Service with the Law Council. We understand that the matters concerned in its letter were based on the 1989 Bill to a great extent and not especially to the Bill before the chamber.

We are not really fully aware of whether there are still outstanding matters of serious concern for the Law Council, but we are not disposed at this stage either to oppose or to amend the legislation. We believe that the new procedure of referring the Bill to the legislation Standing Committee for more detailed scrutiny will enable any remaining concerns of the Law Council to be given deeper study. On receipt of the Committee report, the Opposition will then be in a position to express a view on any proposed amendments coming from that Committee. As I said, the Opposition does not oppose the legislation; in fact, we support the aims of the Government on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make it quite clear at the outset that, while the Australian Democrats will not be opposing the Customs (Detention and Search) Bill 1990, we do have some reservations about its ultimate effectiveness. As always, in this area of legislative action there is a need to balance civil liberties concerns against the protection of the community, that is, the public good. In recent years this Government has brought forward a range of measures in the crime fighting and drug control category. Broadly speaking, the Democrats have supported these measures while continuing to place proper emphasis on their efficiency and, indeed, the need to protect individual rights.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable senators are aware, this Bill repeals the current power to detain and search people suspected of unlawfully carrying prohibited goods, and inserts in its place a new division containing a more comprehensive range of Customs detention and search powers. These new provisions bring together the full range of Customs body search powers: from the least intrusive frisk, through external search, to the most intrusive internal search. Quite properly, as the powers given to Customs officers in relation to searches are strengthened, the legal requirements on those officers are made more rigorous.

At present, Customs officers only have the power to conduct either an external search or an internal search and these searches must be ordered by a justice of the peace or the Comptroller-General of Customs. The order must then be based on reasonable suspicion. Searches must be carried out by a person of the same sex or, in the case of an internal search, by a medical practitioner.

This current regime is open to criticism on civil liberties grounds in that it does not provide for searches to be carried out in private, there is inadequate protection for minors, there is no provision for interpreter assistance for non-English speaking suspects, and the right of detainees to a lawyer needs to be strengthened. In these respects, this legislation tightens up and improves on the current situation. It is clearly preferable to have powers and obligations arising from those powers spelt out in the legislation so that both Customs officials and suspects are better protected.

The Australian Customs Service has had this legislation on its drawing board for some years and, to its credit and to the credit of the Government, there has been consultation with civil liberties, human rights and privacy groups, and most concerns raised have been addressed in the legislation. By and large, the relevant organisations are happy with the protection afforded to passengers subject to a search.

While it is true that searches necessarily involve some invasion of privacy, apart from not conducting searches at all, as much as possible has been done in this legislation, we believe, to protect a person's rights. I note in particular that the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, whose brief is to examine legislation from the point of view of personal rights and liberties, considers that the rights of individuals are adequately protected under this Bill. In particular, the Committee noted that the Bill actually improves on the present situation, as I have said before.

I want to run briefly through the provisions of the proposed legislation. The Bill provides for three levels of search: a frisk search, an external search and an internal search. The first of these-the frisk search-is restricted to officers of the Customs Service, where an officer suspects on reasonable grounds that a person is carrying illegal goods. The invasion of the suspect's privacy is minimised in this case by the right of the person suspected to have the frisk search conducted in private, if he or she so wishes, and for the search to be conducted by an officer of the same sex.

The second level of search is the slightly more intrusive external search and appropriately the controls put into place for this search are much more stringent. The external search can be undertaken only if ordered by a justice of the peace, the Customs Comptroller-General or an officer of supervisory rank. In this case then, the Customs officer's suspicions must be strong enough to convince one of those persons before the search can proceed. The search must be undertaken in private and by an officer of the same sex.

The most intrusive search is, of course, the third level and controls imposed in relation to it must be commensurately strong. An internal search can be undertaken only where a person is suspected of carrying illegal narcotics in a commercial or trafficable quantity-as opposed to carrying illegal drugs, which is the test applied to the other two levels of search. In the absence of a suspect's consent, an internal search can only proceed following two periods of 48 hours in detention to allow the substance to be emitted naturally. The two periods of detention and the search have to be individually ordered by a magistrate or judge.

A person being held for an internal search has the right for a lawyer to be present or to be represented at the hearings to seek the detention and search order. The internal search must be conducted by a medical practitioner in a hospital and the medical practitioner is provided with immunity from suits which may arise as a result of the search, with the natural exception of negligence.

Most significantly, at all three levels of search the person detained has the right to protection if he or she is a minor or is intellectually or physically incapacitated. Similarly, a suspected person who is not fluent in English has the express right to be given an interpreter. Both compared with the current legislative regime and measured against the yardstick of appropriate protection for individual rights, the Bill is therefore acceptable.

Having looked at that aspect of the proposal, I now want to comment briefly on the contribution this legislation might make to the protection of the community in the area of drug use and drug peddling. It is recognised that drugs represent an ever-growing problem within our society. Honourable senators will be aware of the figures which confirm that assertion and I will not go into them here. It is also true that methods of importation and concealment are becoming increasingly sophisticated and hence the available powers and methods of detection and recovery must also become more sophisticated.

While we acknowledge the magnitude of the problem, the Australian Democrats are not convinced that these new search procedures will make a major contribution to combating the drug problem in this country. Indeed, a different approach altogether is almost certainly required. My colleague Senator Coulter will be discussing this aspect in more detail in his speech.

I also refer in passing to the report by the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority which, in its report on drugs and crime, detailed a number of possible options of how to deal with the drug problem in future. It suggested that the States, as well as the Federal Government, should address these possible alternative options with some urgency. The Customs Service itself acknowledges that it is not in a position to estimate the effectiveness of its efforts in terms of drug availability or abuse. Other reports indicate that the trafficking of illicit drugs to Australia has continued to increase and that there is no evidence that illicit drug seizures have had a major impact on the availability of illicit drugs in Australia, although no doubt these measures will assist in containing it to some extent.

As I said earlier, the Australian Democrats' reservations about the effectiveness of this proposed legislation does not mean we oppose it. However, given its impact on people's privacy, we will be monitoring its implementation very carefully and will move to amend it in future if that becomes necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As my colleague Senator Spindler has already indicated, I will address only one aspect of the Customs (Detention and Search) Bill 1990, and that is the effectiveness of the procedures which, in a philosophical sense, are an extension of the present attitude which the Government has to the control of the use of illicit and other drugs. I note that the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) stated in his second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: In that respect, this part of the Bill-
I refer particularly to the internal body search section-
is similar to the Customs Amendment Act of 1979 which proposed an internal body-search regime, but which was never proclaimed.

So it is useful to emphasise that we are dealing with an attitude which apparently has remained substantially unchanged over the last 11 years. For technical reasons, the Bill was not proclaimed and, in a legislative sense, what we have before us now may be more effective. However, in terms of the attitude to the importation of illicit drugs and the use of those drugs in the community and the problem that that poses for Australian society, the modification of attitudes that has gone on at least in some quarters in Australia is not reflected in this legislation.
Page 17 of the Bill sets out the procedures which will apply to the conduct of an internal search, which is to be conducted by a medical practitioner. The Bill states:

. . . a medical practitioner may, in carrying out an internal search of a detainee under section 219Z, use any medical procedure or apparatus that the medical practitioner considers to be reasonably safe in the circumstances.
The medical practitioner is constrained from using any procedure involving a surgical incision unless he or she considers it necessary to do so because the detainee's life is at risk.

Very extensive powers are given to the medical practitioner under this Bill, and the normal rights of patients with respect to assaults on their person-in other circumstances these would be regarded as assaults on the person because they are done without the permission of the detainee-are abrogated by this legislation. As Senator Spindler has pointed out, we are not objecting to that given the context in which this legislation has come forward. What we are questioning is the effectiveness of that context. The general principle which lies behind this Bill is that by imposing more stringent methods of detention, of search and of the imposition of penalties, in some way we will get on top of this growing problem.

I point then to the report of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, to which my colleague Senator Spindler has already referred. I quote one paragraph from the report last year of that Committee:

Over the past two decades in Australia we have devoted increased resources to drug law enforcement, we have increased the penalties for drug trafficking and we have accepted increasing inroads on our civil liberties as part of the battle to curb the drug trade. All the evidence shows, however, not only that our law enforcement agencies have not succeeded in preventing the supply of illegal drugs to Australian markets but that it is unrealistic to expect them to do so. If the present policy of prohibition is not working then it is time to give serious consideration to the alternatives, however radical they may seem.

On other occasions, as recently as this week, we have drawn attention to the strong desirability of the Government's looking elsewhere for a solution to this problem of increasing crime and the increasing costs associated with the use of illicit drugs.
I note also that in the Minister's second reading speech, on page 8-Senator Newman has already quoted this section-the Minister is there saying:

In 1988-89 the total number of persons searched was 2,505, which represents 0.06 per cent of the total arriving passenger population of 4.2m. Of this number of searches, 102 persons were detained for internal search-
I have calculated that as 0.002 per cent of the total number of people arriving-
and, in most cases, those persons consented to x-ray by medical practitioner.

It goes on to say that it is not expected that that number will increase. It seems to me that that number is sufficiently small to suggest that it is fairly arbitrary, and that, again, these further measures which are included in this legislation are not likely to be effective in stemming the flow of drugs into this country. Most of the 0.002 per cent of people detained agreed to be x-rayed-suggesting that most of them were probably not carrying drugs. An extension of the ability to detain and search that small number of people will probably not be very effective in dealing with this very considerable problem.

It is interesting also to remember that historically a drug such as heroin was freely available in Australia up until about 1940. Indeed, Australia imported more heroin per capita up until about 1940 than any other developed country, and that importation was legal. Here we are today. We are a society that still exists. We still conduct our affairs in a normally civilised manner. We have not descended into a drug-ridden community that is incapable of conducting its affairs rationally, normally and in a civilised manner despite that history of having gone through a period in which heroin was imported in large amounts and under conditions in which it was completely legal.

The narcotic use in Australia-indeed on quite a large scale-is not a new phenomenon in this country, and it has not in the past produced the sorts of problems that many people who are concerned about alternative ways of dealing with this problem suggest might happen. Of course, when narcotics were outlawed, the opportunity was then made for the crime syndicates to move into the trade and operate in ways which were illegal. The syndicates were made illegal by the very act of these drugs themselves being made illegal.

The main criterion for imposing criminal sanctions on particular behaviour is that the behaviour is harmful to others. But I ask the rhetorical question: does this principle justify criminal sanctions against certain drugs given that the crime associated presently with drugs is a direct result of their becoming illegal. In other words, we have made crimes of things which are really medical and social problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —The drugs are neutral.

—The drugs themselves are neutral, of course. Criminalisation has fostered a close and profitable relationship between narcotics and organised crime. Those who have the most to lose from legislation are those with a capital investment in the mechanisms of the black market. It would be interesting to note, if we were to move towards decriminalisation, who would object most to such a proposal. I suggest that it would be more likely to be those involved in the present illegal importation and sale of drugs in this country. The tougher the legal measures against drugs become, the higher the price that can be asked for the drug and the bigger the profits that can be made. Large illegal empires need large and protected distribution networks. Of course, this then has led to these profits which can be made, leading to the corruption of the justice structures in this country and in other countries. It has also led to a considerable amount of crime and violence on the streets. One has only to see what has happened on the streets of cities such as New York recently, and particularly the enormous violence which has broken out in countries such as Colombia, where many people, particularly in politics and in the media, find it impossible to conduct any criticism of the drug crime links without the possibility of being murdered.

SPEECH.PARA: The money invested in illegal drug operations can also be seen as a drain on the world pool of legitimate capital. The world trade in narcotics has been estimated by the United States Senate as around $500 billion a year. If the trade became legal and controlled, with prices which of course would very significantly undercut this black market, the big dealers would be those with most to lose. The drug consumers in Australia-it is estimated that there may be as many as 30,000 to 50,000 people who are dependent on heroin, and perhaps as many as 60,000 recreational but non-dependent users-are at present totally at the mercy of an unregulated market. They are moved on to more lucrative and dangerous substances through artificial supply restrictions. Criminality amongst users trying to pay the inflated prices is widespread and one of the enormous drains, of course, on our present police forces is the degree of breaking and entering of homes and other premises, the petty and not so petty pilfering that goes on, the prostitution and the various other activities that are carried out in an attempt to pay for illegal drugs. The damage done by most narcotics arises principally from the fact that the trade is illegal.

Death and illness among drug users is not predominantly caused by the consumption of the drugs; it is caused by the unregulated doses of drugs, by impurities mixed with the drugs and by the unhygienic conditions associated particularly with the intravenous use of drugs. On a previous occasion I dealt at some length with the risk posed to the Australian community from the acquired immune deficiency syndrome because of the use of injectable drugs and the sharing of needles.

So we simply wish to stress, as my colleague Senator Spindler indicated, that, while we are not opposing this legislation, we do see it as an extension of a system of control of drug importation and use which has demonstrably failed and which needs to be modified. The modification would be associated with an improvement in the health of the community, a decrease in crime, a decrease in the cost of law enforcement and, hopefully, a much safer and more humane society.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority Bill 1990 is to transfer the functions of the Maritime Operations Division of the Department of Transport and Communications to a new statutory authority. As outlined in the second reading speech by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), the functions of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) are to be the coordination of maritime research and rescue services; administration of the national plan to combat pollution from ships; implementation of maritime safety and pollution prevention conventions on Australian and visiting foreign ships; the provision of navigational aids and of safety radio services to shipping through the Overseas Telecommunications Commission; the setting of standards for the education, training and certification of seafarers; the operation of the seamen's engagement system; the operation of the Australian register of ships; promotion of sea safety for small craft; and representation at the International Maritime Organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the Bill, responsibility for investigations of marine casualties will remain with the Department of Transport and Communications. As pointed out by the Minister, the functions being transferred to the Authority have all been effectively performed by the Department, and Australia has an excellent record in maritime safety.

When the Bill was introduced into the House of Representatives it had three features: firstly, to establish a statutory authority, the Australian Maritime Safety Authority; secondly, to locate the new statutory authority at Newcastle; and, thirdly, to establish the Authority at a cost of $10m which has been estimated to have blown out to $17m or in excess of $17m.

The question must be asked: What is the purpose of establishing yet another statutory authority? The Government argues that it represents corporatisation or commercialisation. If that were the main compelling reason as a step towards privatisation, it would have some merit. What the Government is doing, however, by various mechanisms-and this is one of them-is, firstly, to get revenue and expenditure off Budget, and, secondly, to reduce accountability to the Parliament and thus the people of Australia.

The Government has in recent times established a series of trust accounts within departments which lend themselves to this course. They are what are called quasi-commercial operations. The original intention had some merit in that it was, I understand, meant to place them in a competitive position with equivalent-type operations within the private sector. However, it has not gone in the direction that the Department of Finance would have liked it to have gone because these quasi-commercial groups have a large number of captive clients within the public sector itself. This not only enables them to cover fixed costs at monopoly rates, but also to compete with the private sector, using, if they wish, marginal costing; there are numerous examples of this already occurring. It is exactly the same principle as in the domestic prices for primary products in Europe being used to subsidise rural producers, to which everybody on both sides of this Parliament objects. So what we are seeing are subsidies being given through tied clients to make government business enterprises appear to be competitive and efficient.

What has attracted the Government, however, to trust accounts, in the case of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority, a statutory corporation, is that revenue and expenditure go off budget. With trust accounts, to a large extent what goes off one department's budget will, of course, go onto another department's budget. A great problem to the Parliament is the ability of individual members and senators to be able to trace that process.

With statutory corporations, as is the case with AMSA, where a fee is charged for service the revenue and expenditure are all off budget. While not objecting to a user pays concept for service, what it does enable the Government to do is to impose whatever charge it likes on to a group of captive clients who have no option but to pay. It is thus another government charge and a further indirect tax on that particular sector of the community which has no option but to pay. However, more importantly, it is a way of hiding government revenue and expenditure. The cumulative effect enables the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Government, quite incorrectly, to hoodwink the community and the media by claiming that they have reduced government revenue and government expenditure. At a time when there is a greater and greater demand in the community for transparency, the setting up of yet another quango is not the way to go. For the reasons outlined earlier, the Opposition will be opposing this Bill.

What a litany of deceit we have had on the location of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. When the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) raised in the House the real reason behind the location of AMSA and the expenditure of around $17m in the vicinity of the electorate of the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown), this was greeted with outrage by the Minister and his colleagues. It is worth quoting a few of the responses. In the House of Representatives on 22 August, reported at page 1282 of Hansard, the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) said:

There is no parish pumping; there was no need for there to be. But to choose Canberra would be unbelievable parish pumping . . . would look absolutely stupid, and it would be stupid. Yet we have the audacity of this nonsense about parish pumping.
On the same day the honourable member for Newcastle said:
I pay tribute to the Minister for Land Transport, who initiated this legislation. I take umbrage at the insult that was offered by the shadow Minister regarding the location.

Then in the House of Representatives the new honourable member for Adelaide (Dr Catley), reported at page 1334 of Hansard, gave us one of the major reasons for locating at Newcastle-this is great stuff from the Government's decision making process-when he said:
. . . Newcastle is adjacent to the best winemaking area in Australia.
It is no wonder that Australia has economic problems if this represents the decision-making process of the Australian Labor Party! Then the Minister for Land Transport, reported on page 1338, said:
While some of the comments may have been a little facetious, honourable members generally would appreciate and understand why AMSA will continue to be located in Canberra.
He went on further:
It is just coincidental that my electorate adjoins Newcastle.
And he said further:
I emphasise that the decision to locate AMSA in Newcastle was based on objective reasons.
So we had the high dudgeon of these people associated with the Newcastle area claiming that what the member for Gilmore had said on pump priming was abusive to them.

Following all those indignant protests during the debate, a sensible note was introduced by Senator Walsh, who sprung the Government when he said, among other things, `Circuses are taking over from the real issues and such a move has no functional purpose'. It is quite apparent that, with the ringmaster on the back bench, the clowns are now running the circus.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I ask him: When did the Australian Government first receive any indication from the United States Government that it wished to withdraw from the North West Cape communications facility?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.
