TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of an article in the West Australian newspaper last Monday, 17 September, written by Brian Toohey entitled `A cosy relationship denies the workers'? Does the Minister agree with Mr Toohey's opinion that the leadership of the Australian Council of Trade Unions shares a cosy relationship with the Treasurer and that this works against the interests of union members?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see the article by Brian Toohey, which I understand is nationally syndicated. I saw the version published in Monday's West Australian. If we expect of journalists as we do of witnesses in court proceedings to tell the truth, the whole truth and nothing else but the truth, we have to recognise that the art of rendering the truth in journalistic copy is indeed a difficult art. But even with that qualification borne in mind, this article does not meet the whole truth element of what we would expect to be a reasonable report.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Toohey has written an article which is selective in the extreme. He has selected to suit his particular brand of prejudice. There can be no argument that he has eschewed objectivity in the putting of his point of view. Therefore, the proximity to truth in reporting that his article bears is indeed a distant one.

I propose to comment only briefly on the point raised by Senator McKiernan. It is true-there is nothing surprising about it; it would be odd if it were otherwise-that the union movement has a proximity to a Labor government that it might not have to a Liberal government. There is a closeness. In fact, we have an accord to help regulate industrial relations. The managing of that is a difficult enough job in order to keep all the elements of that accord travelling in the right direction for the positive outcome of the economy. To characterise the interconnection between a representative of the union movement and the Government as some sort of conspiracy, as the article seems to imply, is to characterise it entirely in the obverse direction to where it really is-it is an essential element to proper management.

Mr Toohey has repeated an old canard in his article that the Opposition used in the election campaign-I see that Mr Howard still uses it-by simply and mindlessly saying that under Labor real wages have fallen. That is true because there has been a change in factor shares from wages to profits-as the accord was designed to do-in order to generate profits for investment and encourage investment in Australia. But what that canard does not recognise, which is the whole truth and which is left unstated in this article, is the fact that disposable household income per capita, which is the real test of the well-being of ordinary Australians, has risen by over 11 per cent during the period of this Government.

Just simply mindlessly repeating that real wages have fallen ignores the fact that there is an 11 per cent improvement in household disposable income per capita. The well-being of households is dependent on wages, on taxes, on other services provided and on the social wage.

The social wage is the other flaw in what Mr Toohey has said. In his article he has ignored any commentary-he purports to speak as if he were a Labor man but condemns the Labor Government-that the biggest tax cuts in Australia's history, combined with measures to reduce tax avoidance, have been introduced by this Government; that we have extended occupational superannuation to the greater bulk of wage and salary earners, including women, who have been traditionally excluded; that we have introduced the family allowance supplement and Medicare; that we have introduced housing assistance, which was not provided before; that we have made significant improvements in the provisions of child-care; and that there has been a dramatic movement in the retention rate in secondary schools, with year 12 rates having increased by 36 per cent in 1982 and by 60 per cent in 1989. When looking at the well-being of families, it is not simply a matter of the real value of wages; it is the real purchasing power, the real household disposable income, that is the test. Chaney, Howard and Toohey make a trinity in not recognising those objective truths.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to a report in today's Australian that a confidential Government report from the Bureau of Industry Economics (BIE) was obtained by the media and that that report recommends more deregulation in the banking system. I ask the Minister: Does he agree with the report's statement that the relative lack of competition in the Australian market has allowed the banks to maintain artificially high lending margins? Does this indicate the failure of the Treasurer's method of deregulating the financial system? Does the Minister agree that there would have been even more competition in the Australian banking industry if foreign banks, granted entry several years ago, had been allowed to operate in Australia as branches rather than being required to operate through subsidiaries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very easy for some people to leap to conclusions. On the basis of the advice or the minute I have received from the Bureau of Industry Economics I am not able to leap to any conclusions of that kind. The BIE offers independent advice on a variety of economic issues. The costs and availability of capital to industry are as major a concern to it, as they are to me.

ANSWER.PARA: The burden of the BIE paper was to make the point that Australian banks appear to be enjoying lending margins double those obtaining in the United Kingdom at the present time. The United Kingdom comparison was chosen because monetary policy there followed a very similar course to monetary policy in Australia. The distorting influences of changes in monetary policy on lending margins is taken into account in such a comparison.

The implication of that is that the costs of capital to business borrowing domestically is higher than those justified by the current circumstance of monetary policy. That is not a novel conclusion. I have made some comments about that before and I believe other Ministers have too. The Treasurer made that point a few weeks ago in some statement relating to the banks. The BIE also concluded that the banks may now be seeking to recoup some of the losses experienced recently as a result of bankruptcies and the collapse of some highly leveraged entrepreneurs.

As to whether this indicates a lack of competition in the Australian market and that more competition would occur if additional banking licences were made available to operate only in certain market segments, as I indicated in the earlier part of my answer I am not in a position to say for sure. That may well be the case. It may be an issue worthy of examination. However, I am sure that the behaviour of the capital market has not been subject to as much scrutiny as other sectors of the economy in the so-called public micro- economic reform debate.

In terms of the need to make capital available to small to medium sized firms to enable them to grow and develop new products and services, our capital markets have proved to be narrow and inflexible in their lending practices. In particular, the thinness of the venture capital market in Australia appears to be just as much a product of cultural attitudes amongst the institutions as it is of market structure.
In answer to Senator Short's question, in summary all I can say is that any conclusions one can draw from that are speculative ones and I would not draw them at this time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Could I ask the Minister whether he knows how the media obtained a copy of this supposedly confidential report and, if not, what steps he is taking to find out the source of the leak?
—I am ignorant about that matter, and I regard this particular ignorance as bliss.

—Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade indicate what is the Australian Government's response to the continued violence in Sri Lanka and, in particular, the reports of human rights violations? Is there any scope for action by the Australian Government to help promote the resumption of negotiations between the Sri Lankan Government and the Tamil Tigers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government is extremely concerned by the situation in Sri Lanka, as I know many other Australians are, including Senator Hill, who has been quite vocal-appropriately so-on the subject. We are concerned about the bloodshed, especially the deaths of non-combatants; about the breaches of human rights; and about the implications of the conflict for Sri Lanka's future as a nation.

ANSWER.PARA: I have expressed this concern publicly on a number of occasions, particularly with regard to the actions of the LTTE or the Tamil Tigers. I realise that the LTTE has denied its involvement in massacres, as has generally been its practice throughout the conflict. I can only say that the weight of evidence is overwhelmingly against it.

That is not to say that human rights breaches have not been committed by others. There have been instances of human rights violations on both sides, and I am disturbed that the number of these continues to escalate. Certainly, there is no question of me or the Australian Government condoning abuses perpetrated by the Government security forces. I believe that the Sri Lankan Government has been making genuine efforts to ensure effective discipline among its forces. In my discussions in Colombo recently I emphasised the need to sustain these efforts. Subsequent to my visit, the High Commission in Colombo has been instructed to remind the Sri Lankan Government of the need for restraint, particularly in view of some alarming reports of heavy casualties among Tamil civilians in the east of the country.

In view of our growing concerns about the situation and our firm belief in the need for a negotiated political settlement, I discussed with President Premadasa ways of making progress toward a settlement, including the possibility of involvement by the Commonwealth or some other appropriate multilateral mechanism. Following further consideration of the matter after my return to Australia, the Prime Minister has now written to President Premadasa to set out some options in the Commonwealth context which the Sri Lankans might like to pursue. These options concentrate on a possible Commonwealth good offices role to facilitate resumption of negotiations between the Sri Lankan Government and the LTTE. The Opposition spokesman on foreign affairs and trade, Senator Hill, has been fully briefed on this subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications to a recent significant paper on Telecom Australia's community service obligations by the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics, which noted that competition will force Telecom to adopt a pricing structure which includes charges for directory assistance, higher rental charges, timed local calls and higher STD charges for remote rural consumers. ANSWER.PARA: One of the constant targets for attack in Australia is Telecom, and I agree with the Australian Democrats and a number of others that Telecom is often unfairly and unjustly criticised in that, at least from where I sit, it provides a relatively efficient service. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. Is it true that a Boeing 707 en route to Sydney was forced to land at Williamtown Airport last Saturday due to a lack of fuel? Is it true that this incident forced the closure of Williamtown Airport? Was there any danger to residents living in the vicinity of the Williamtown Airport?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, it is true. Last week was not a good week for aviation in Australia involving big jets. But what it indicated was something which I have always held to be true and something to which the Chairman of the Civil Aviation Authority has recently been giving a great deal of attention, because of which some very unfair criticism has been levelled at him: that is, to attain an excellent safety record, which many countries around the world have, one needs a combination of factors involving the strict regulation, supervision and workmanship that go into the original construction of the aircraft; the quality of the maintenance that is then delivered to that aircraft during its entire working life; and the expertise of all of the multiple systems involved in regulating the passage of that aircraft through the air in relation to other aircraft, that is, the skill of the crew on board the aircraft, air traffic control and the quality of the equipment that is involved in all of those stages.

ANSWER.PARA: If all of those factors are very closely regulated, what we end up with is an excellent safety record. However, in order to achieve a perfect safety record in big jets, which this country has, we need a fourth element: a lot of luck. That is precisely indicated, regrettably, by the incidents last week.

The week started with a well-publicised incident on the main runway at Sydney Airport, where there was almost a collision between two 747s, one with a large number of passengers on board and the other an empty Qantas Airways Ltd 747 being towed across the runway. It would not have been the fault of Qantas if the two aircraft had collided and there had been quite a number of deaths, but its record would have been spoiled by having a broken aeroplane. There was, of course, an incident on the same evening near Phuket in Thailand.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was nowhere near the take-off point.

—We will not have to say `Senator Michael Baume', regrettably, for much longer; we will just say `Senator Baume', because he will be the only Baume here. I am sorry about that. When I read the newspapers this morning I did not understand Senator Bishop's vitriolic attack on former Senator Puplick, but I do now.
—Order! We perhaps should go back to aircraft.

—With the incident near Phuket, where a Galaxy almost collided with a Qantas 747, it was only luck that there were not 360 dead passengers. In the same week, on the following Saturday-Senator Faulkner's information is correct-a Nigerian Boeing 707 en route from Honolulu to Sydney reported to air traffic control when it was 500 kilometres from Sydney that it had only 45 minutes of fuel left. It was diverted to Williamtown Airport. The Nigerian registered Boeing 707 was a freighter carrying 30 bloodstock horses, 10 grooms and six crew.

ANSWER.PARA: Government senators-There was no shortage of horsepower.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right; it was just a problem with the fuel. The aircraft was diverted to Williamtown. While the aircraft was on its final approach to the airport, the two outboard engines flamed out due to fuel exhaustion. A third engine flamed out as the plane touched down on the runway.

ANSWER.PARA: The aircraft stayed on the runway and air traffic control requested it to move off the runway so that an F18 fighter could land. The pilot responded that he was unable to move the aircraft from the runway to the taxiway as he was out of fuel. Regrettably, the airport then had to be closed for three hours while the aircraft was refuelled on the runway in order to move it off the runway.

The incident was very regrettable. Both the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation and the Civil Aviation Authority are currently investigating it. The Bureau has already given me a preliminary report which says that the preliminary investigation has already revealed that there seemed to have been a substantial problem with fuel management on behalf of the crew. I have no doubt that the report, when it is completed, will contain further details which I can provide to Senator Faulkner at that time.

I cannot say at this point in time whether there was any real danger to the community near Williamtown airport except to say-in acknowledging the facts, as I have to Senator Faulkner-that the aircraft landed at Williamtown literally with the fuel in the fuel lines running to the engines and none in the tanks. It was luck, again, and the prompt action of the controller who diverted it to Williamtown, that saved what could have been the third disaster in one week.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Has his attention been drawn to the statement of 12 September by the Opposition spokesman on primary industry which alleges that the Government has 'deliberately misled the public over the effects of importing apples from New Zealand?' Does this statement also accuse the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service of 'blatant distortion of the facts' on this issue in a recent edition of the AQIS bulletin? TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of a report on labour turnover and absenteeism in the Australian automotive industry prepared by the Automotive Industry Council? What are the major findings of the report and what initiatives will the Government undertake to address the issues raised?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must commend Senator Foreman for raising this question. We talk in this community about the level of industrial disputes as a major factor for lost time in production, but we do not talk anywhere near seriously enough about the lost time caused by industrial accidents, injury and disease in industry, which is by a factor 12 times more than the dispute level. However, we do not talk at all about the lost time to production because of absenteeism and labour turnover, which is also stated, at least by some commentators to be about the same level as lost time due to accidents. It is in approaching the subject of how to increase productivity and improve the time out of industry by the productive inputs that this question becomes important.

ANSWER.PARA: A group of consultants put a report to the Automotive Industry Council, which covered 2,300 employees at 11 automotive industry plants throughout Australia, representing approximately 10 per cent of the employees at those plants. The major findings of the report were that in 1989 labour turnover rates for companies participating in the study varied from 11 per cent to 61 per cent per annum with a median of 28 per cent. The turnover costs were about $6,600 for each non-trade employee and up to $71,000 for each manager. Turnover and absenteeism add almost $850, it was found, to the cost of a car. The key underlying factor influencing turnover, absenteeism and motivation was the worker's commitment to the organisation, and the most important determinant of the worker's attitude overall was the managerial style used. The report stressed the need for an open management style with an emphasis on consultation and open and fair decision making.

The findings of the report are consistent with the findings of similar reports in the past in that there is a recognition of a need to introduce new organisation and managerial style to ensure job satisfaction. It is recognised that it does make a difference, as some workers have said. In organisations where a new open managerial style has been introduced, it has been found that when people clock on they are not required to leave their brains at the gate; they can take them in and apply them to the production tasks that they do there. All the abilities of an employee are used, not just the mechanistic aspect of his or her skill contribution. Award restructuring has been a positive help and the workplace reform program that this Government runs has also helped improve the quality of working life and the quality of productivity.

I conclude by saying that in the automotive industry the Government has undertaken a number of programs. In 1988 the Department of Industrial Relations part funded a tripartite overseas mission to Japan, the United States of America, West Germany and Sweden to investigate best practice in the industry. As a consequence of that visit a study of work groups at Toyota is being carried out by Dr Bamber of the University of Queensland on a grant. The Toyota Dandenong plant is pioneering the work teams concept in the automotive industry in Australia and will report in March 1991.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

In view of the fundamental importance for the national interest of major micro-economic reform, and noting that improved efficiency and greater competition are key elements of such reform, the need for the Senate to endorse the selling of shares in the Commonwealth Bank, Qantas and Australian Airlines.

Let me make it clear what the debate on this urgency motion today is about and what it is not about. It is not a debate about the merits or demerits of privatisation. It is not about debating whether publicly owned business undertakings would make more efficient use of our community's scarce resources if they were run by the private sector. It is not about whether privatisation, with necessary supporting measures, would increase competition or give consumers a wide range of better quality goods and services to choose from and at lower prices. It is not about whether employees in public enterprises would be better off if those enterprises were owned by private shareholders, with the employees having the option to be shareholders in their own enterprises on preferential terms. The debate is not about whether privatisation of government-owned business enterprises would lead to higher national productivity and increased national competitiveness in an ever-increasingly competitive international environment; or about whether this increased productivity, efficiency and competitiveness would produce faster economic growth, more jobs and higher incomes in Australia.

The debate is not about these matters for one simple reason, namely that that debate has already been held and won throughout most of the Australian community, just as it has been held and won throughout virtually all the Western world and most of the Third World. Privatisation is no longer an issue for debate in much of the world.

More than 90 governments of all political persuasions around the world-democracies, single party governments and dictatorships alike-have full-scale privatisation of publicly owned enterprises as a major plank of their economic reform programs and policies. The number of countries going down the privatisation route is, of course, accelerating rapidly. One has only to observe the momentous changes occurring throughout eastern Europe. Is it not incredible that in nations which less than 12 months ago were run by hard core, reactionary communist governments, privatisation is proceeding at a pace that makes Australia under the Hawke Government look even more out of touch with modern day reality than is the case.

One of the few groups on earth yet to embrace the necessity for privatisation, if we want to improve the living standards of our people, is the Australian Labor Party (ALP). Regrettably, the Labor Party appears to be joined in this time warp of unreality by the Australian Democrats, although I earnestly hope and pray that the Democrats today will support this urgency motion so as to prove my assessment of them wrong.

But setting the Democrats aside, this debate today is all about providing the Australian Labor Party at its special national conference next Monday with overwhelming evidence that the elected representatives of the Australian people, in the form of members of this Senate, representing as we do all shades of political opinion and all States and territories of this nation, recognise the urgent need for the party of the present Federal Government, albeit only for a brief time yet, the Australian Labor Party, to face reality and to pursue policies which will lead to a better way of life for all Australians-policies which are not dictated by faction and division within the Party, policies of the least common denominator.

There are many things that need to be done to make Australia once again a vibrant, dynamic, prosperous, compassionate nation with rising living standards. But in the end, these many things boil down to this: we must become more productive, we must become more competitive, we must use the physical and human resources with which we are so amply blessed more efficiently in the interests of us all as citizens of Australia and as bequeathers of this great nation of ours to our children and our children's children.

Why is it that, despite all our endowments, our resources, our skills, our talents and our capacities, our per capita economic output is one of the lowest in the Western world and far lower than the leading so-called Third World countries? Why is it that our costs of living increase each year at twice the rate of most other Western nations-in some instances, four or five times their rate? Why is it that our interest rates are the highest in the Western world and cripple families and businesses alike? Why is it that we cannot pay our way in the world? Why do we buy $20,000m more worth of goods and services each year from other countries than we are able to sell to them? Why, as a result, has our debt to the rest of the world-the mortgage we will bequeath to our children and grandchildren-increased no less than fivefold in the past seven brief years?

The basic reason is that we do not use our resources efficiently. One basic reason for this is that we have most of our infrastructure-our essential industries that provide the power, the communications and the transport and all the other services that are essential for the efficient working of a modern economy-owned by governments, both Federal and State.

It is totally beyond dispute that publicly owned enterprises are less efficient in the use of resources than privately owned enterprises. There is a library of studies to support this view. If we want to get out of the dreadful mess that the Hawke Labor Government has got us into, one of the essential, urgent actions required is to permit the privatisation of our major publicly owned enterprises. That is what next week's special ALP conference is all about. Will the Labor Party at last grasp the nettle and take the decision to sell the shares in the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines, or will it not?

There are two aspects of this question that I want to pursue. The first is the quite disgraceful hypocrisy, confusion, illogicality and inconsistency shown by leading members of the Government on this subject over recent years. My colleagues, Senator Macdonald and Senator Olsen will elaborate on this later in the debate. The second point I want to raise is the fact that these fundamental decisions are in the hands of a bunch of unknown faceless people whom the Australian electorate has had no part at all in selecting for this task.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are in a time warp, senator.

—The honourable senator is in a time warp. His Party has been in a time warp for the last 80 years. Let me address Labor's cant and hypocrisy first. But before doing that, let me point out that within Labor's ranks the battle has already been lost to the troglodytes in respect of privatisation in the telecommunications industry. Cabinet has adopted the Beazley megacom or monstercom proposal. That proposal keeps Telecom Australia and OTC Ltd totally government owned. The proposed permitted sale of Aussat Pty Ltd is but a minnow in this sea of whales, although even that tiny decision is up for grabs at next week's conference.

SPEECH.PARA: The Keating proposal on communications was a less bad proposal than the Beazley proposal, but it too was grossly deficient in its failure to recognise the need to privatise the telecommunications industry and to introduce genuine competition, both of which are full-blooded publicly known and promoted policies of the Opposition. The main privatisation battle lines for next week's special conference are drawn around the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines Ltd.

TALK.START.PARA: —No they are not. You are wrong.

—The honourable senator should read his special resolution. Confusion on these matters reigns supreme within Labor's ranks. No wonder there is confusion, fear and concern throughout the ranks of the Labor Party. Let us have a look at some of the statements of leading players in recent years. Let us have a look at what Mr Keating had to say on this subject in the House of Representatives in 1985. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: No matter where one looks, whether it be at TAA or the other authorities, there is no case for the Opposition's argument in economics except simply to indulge ideologically in a Thatcherite, vandalistic splurge to try to destroy these authorities.

the Opposition sits back and says that it will sell off Telecom, Australia Post, the Commonwealth Bank, or any of the others. The Labor Party will fight tooth and nail to keep these public authorities in the hands of the Commonwealth . . . We are not about wrecking them and selling them. The great public services they provide will continue to be provided while ever this Government has the breath to defend them.
Again, in the same debate in the House of Representatives in 1985 Mr Keating stated:
The sale of the Commonwealth Bank or the Australian Industry Development Corporation-
to the Government's credit it has been partially privatised-
or Trans-Australia Airlines is simply vandalism of Australia's great public authorities.
In 1985 the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that privatisation:
. . . is a one-off fire sale, the sale of the century, of your assets-the assets of the people of Australia.
They would transfer them into the hands of a privileged few, to the cost of every one of us.

Even Senator Button, who normally speaks reasonably rational-certainly less irrational-economic commonsense than his counterparts, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Keating), was enjoined to join this Greek chorus. At about the same time in the Senate, he stated:

. . . Privatisation is not about small government as some people allege; it is not about cutting taxes in some sort of fire sale mentality . . . it is most unfortunate . . . the leader . . . should devote so much time to pursuing this ridiculous red herring . . .

In recent times the Prime Minister and the Treasurer seem to have had an apparent conversion on the Damascus road. I use the words `apparent conversion' advisedly and deliberately because nowhere that I look in the ranks of the Labor Party, in the so-called think tanks of the Labor Party, and in the policy documents emanating from the Labor Party, can I find one whit of evidence that there has been a detailed and carefully thought-out reconsideration of this whole question.

However, now the Prime Minister and the Treasurer seem to think that privatisation is not all that bad after all. Indeed, going back to 1988 the Prime Minister started to look as if he was being converted. In an Age newspaper interview in February 1988 he stated:
I do believe it is reasonable to ask does it make sense to tie up public resources in, for instance, running an airline. I have a prima facie view that it doesn't.
Treasurer Keating said the same thing two or three months later. In an AM interview he said:

. . . basically, I don't think the Government ought to be running airlines. And that's why I think their equity ought to be sold down. We can't afford to continue providing subventions for their capital base. Now with scarce Cabinet Room budgetary dollars, we can't be putting billions into Qantas and Australian Airlines and the like.

Now, why these apparent conversions by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer? It is because they know that the public purse does not have the dollars to provide these public enterprises with the capital funds necessary for their efficient operation. They also know that these enterprises will not be as efficient as they should whilst they remain in public ownership. The tragedy is that they still cannot bring themselves to throw off the socialist mantle of the traditional Labor Party and its platform. They are prevented from throwing off that mantle by the faceless people of the Labor Party and the organisation of the Labor Party.

Let us look at the letter that was sent to all members of the Australian Labor Party. It was signed jointly by Messrs Hawke and Keating and dated 7 September, following the decision by the Hawke Government and the victorious Kirner Government to sell the State Bank of Victoria to the Commonwealth Bank and to allow the Commonwealth Bank to partially privatise in order to fund that merger. In that letter the Prime Minister and the Treasurer said that there were two points that had to be made at the outset in relation to this decision. They said:
First, the merger decisions were taken to avert the serious possibility of a collapse not only of the State Bank of Victoria, but also, as a result, of the financial system as a whole.

That is simply untrue. There was another bid for the State Bank of Victoria at that time. Why then did they make that point? They did so because they wanted to avert the argument that the merger is important because it challenges the whole foundation of the Labor Party. There is no point in principle about it; it is just a salvage operation. They went on to say:
Second, the merger and injection of new, non-government capital will see the integrity and commercial capacity of a government-owned bank-the Commonwealth-both preserved and strengthened.
Messrs Keating and Hawke could not even bring themselves in that letter to use the words `private capital'; they had to say `non-government capital'. They went on to say:
We believe this is thoroughly consistent with the principles and intentions of Labor's policies towards the Commonwealth Bank despite the reduction from full to majority government ownership.

On what belief is that based? As I have said, this decision overturns those cherished traditional principles and myths of Labor Party history. But Mr Hawke and Mr Keating are not prepared to bite the bullet, face reality and say, `Privatisation is the way to go. The socialist mantle we have had as our traditional base for our Party over the last 80 years is no longer sufficient in this modern-day world. We are prepared to face up to the reality that that implies'.

Labor cannot have it both ways. It cannot continue to straddle the fence. If Labor is really serious about its move towards privatisation, it must be prepared to dump socialism from its party platform. The Opposition's plea today has been the consistent plea for a long time now, and it is a twofold plea. The first part is, `For heaven's sake, be sincere about your privatisation policy'; and secondly, `Stop trying to have two bob each way. Face up to reality. We on this side of the Parliament will support you'. If the Labor Party does not face up to reality and does not bite the bullet, the losers will be the Australian people, and they are the constituents of all members of this House on all sides. The other loser will be the Australian nation. I hope that rationality will prevail and that the shibboleths, the hypocrisy, the cant, the fears and the concerns generated within the ranks of the Labor Party will to be swept away. But I wonder whether that will happen. One only has to look at the philosophical-type speeches by the Prime Minister in the past to realise that it is very doubtful that that will be the case.

We come back to the fact that next Monday's fundamental decisions are in the hands of a group of faceless people who have no claim to democratically represent the Australian electorate or even the Labor Party. There are 101 delegates to the conference next week. Of those, less than one in five are members of the Federal Parliament. Yet that conference will be taking decisions that it is the right of this Parliament to take, and the right of a democratically elected government to take. It is not the right of a bunch of people who have never been elected to represent the people of Australia. In the end we shall have a situation next Monday in which 20 people from the Centre Left of the factions of the Labor Party will decide the fate of the future of the Labor Party and therefore, so long as it remains in government, the fate of the policy making of this country.

Let there be no doubt about it: this special conference of faceless men is a conference that should not be happening. The Government of this country should have the guts, the ability and the wit to tell the Australian people the situation as it is. That situation is clearly that privatisation is the only route to go towards a more efficient Australia. That is what this motion today is about. If the Senate by passing this motion can assist that cause, we will have performed a very valuable service. I urge all honourable senators to support the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make it clear from the outset that the Government will not be supporting this cheap stunt and will be voting against the motion. The reason is fairly simple. SPEECH.PARA: Whether or not there is to be any sale of shares in any of those bodies, some of which will be under discussion on Monday and some of which will not be, will be seen from the legislation which will come forward after it has been properly considered, not by the national conference of any political party, but by the Cabinet. After it has made its decision and the matters have gone through the parliamentary party process, not dissimilar to those pursued by the Opposition party, then it will come before the Parliament. If that happens, the Senate can make its decision in its proper and constitutional way. What is happening in this chamber today is a terrible waste of time and a bit of a diversion, but at least it is the first time the Opposition has come up with any matter of public importance or urgency motion. I suppose we should be grateful for that.

The motion is fundamentally flawed internally, apart from the politics of it. The arguments within it do not lead logically to the conclusion. I agree with the need for micro-economic reform and that the purpose of it is to increase efficiency in the economy, to increase output, and to deal with the problems we have with the current account deficit and giving us the capacity to do that while easing downward pressure on demand because we can increase supply. Increase of supply is slower than reduction of demand, as we all know, but that is a reality with which we have to deal. Micro-economic reform is one part of it. However, there is nothing in the motion that does anything about the question of competition, which has been thrown in there just because Opposition members realise that if they left it out, it would look like the truth-that they are privatising for the sake of it.

Competition is sometimes the appropriate process to do with micro-economic reform-not on every occasion, but on some occasions. Micro-economic reform in probably the most important area, railways, probably will not be affected by competition. It is still micro-economic reform and it is still about efficiency, but it is not about competition. Sometimes it is part of the process. The Opposition vaguely alludes to the fact that there are some other elements, but does not say what they are. The motion and the argument in support of it certainly lack intellectual rigour. There is no argument; it is a question of assertion and fond hope-talking about libraries of argument without mentioning any of it.

Selling shares in enterprises may in some circumstances lead to increased efficiency; not necessarily, and not always, but sometimes. I will quote, from that library, some of the studies that have been done. The selling of shares in those three enterprises or any other has nothing to do with competition. I think that was thrown in as an afterthought. It is inherent nonsense. By definition, selling shares has nothing to do with competition and the Opposition knows it. The Commonwealth Bank operates in a competitive environment. It is valid to argue that it is not a sufficiently competitive environment and that there are some problems with the competition. But it has nothing to do with the share ownership of the Commonwealth Bank. Qantas Airways Ltd operates in a very competitive environment-far more competitive than when Opposition members were in government. There is much more competition with Qantas now that there are many more airlines flying into Australia-and a good thing, too. Australian Airlines Ltd will be competing in a more competitive environment, but that has nothing to do with the share ownership of Australian; it is to do with the proper policy of this Government to do with deregulation, which those opposite always fail to address.

There is a body of academic evidence that says that, with deregulation, the tendency to oligopoly in airline industries will create a problem with competition and that there is a tendency to monopoly. We might have to look at how we deal with that issue. That is what a substantial body of the academic evidence would say. Nevertheless, it is likely, at least in the short term and I hope in the longer term, that there will be enhanced competition as a result, but it has nothing to do with selling shares in any of those enterprises.

I wish to deal with the question of whether it is inherently more efficient, and the evidence is mixed. We find in some of this library of evidence, which Senator Short failed to quote because it does not suit his argument, that the review of our public sector enterprise by Millward and Parker concludes that after an extensive and thorough review of many case studies:

There is no systematic evidence that public enterprises are less cost effective than private firms. The poorer performance, in this respect, exhibited in the studies of refuse collection and water supply . . . has to be balanced against the absence of any significant difference in Canadian railways and Australian airways and the superior performance in US electric power.
Another reviewer, Goodsell, whose work was published in New York, concluded:

To summarise, available comparative data on the efficiency, costs, and quality of services in refuse collection, hospitals, transportation, utilities, and insurance show that whereas at some times business seems superior, at other times government appears to perform better. In still other instances the two sectors do about equally. Hence the results of our survey are mixed but by no means convincingly supportive of the common contention that the private sector always functions better, even according to economic criteria. Moreover, evidence is available to show, perhaps surprisingly to some, that governmental bureaucracy may be less top heavy than private, is capable of impressive productivity gains, and can be just as innovative as private bureaucracy.
More recently an article in the Economic Journal, by Kay and Thompson, concluded:

. . . it does not seem that there is anything intrinsically superior about performance under private ownership . . . There are efficient and inefficient public enterprises and efficient and inefficient private enterprises.

That should not surprise any of us. The recent Australian evidence confirms all that. That is not surprising. In recent years the problem of prudential processes in the banking system has led to the Commonwealth Bank being a far superior performer to some of the private banks. But this is not to say that inherently and therefore public sector instrumentalities will always be more efficient. On the other hand, the State Bank of Victoria comes a long last in the banking sector. A whole lot of Australian private sector enterprise has a performance that is markedly inefficient. I do not have time to go through the list in detail, but Mr Hartnell's 16 is a good place to start the list of the companies which have failed to perform. It is not just a problem for the shareholders; it is a fundamental problem for the Australian economy and for all Australian citizens who share some of the burdens left over from the inadequacy of those performances.

We also have a substantial body of evidence about the recent efficiency under the administration of this Government of both Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines Ltd. Qantas was making virtually nothing in the five years prior to this Government assuming office. Since then it has been regularly providing dividends to the Government-in fact, a record dividend in 1988-89 and substantial dividends totalling $132.7m over the period as a whole. There has been a substantial effective performance by Qantas and also by Australian. Prior to the year when they took a substantial knock because of the pilots dispute, Australian had recorded an operating profit of $108m. This compares with the best year during the Opposition's term of office-$14m-and an average performance of $4m to $5m during its years in government. It is no wonder Opposition members want to sell those enterprises, because they could not run them. They do not need to worry, as they will not get the chance to do so in the foreseeable future.

The Opposition pretends that this matter is urgent. The only thing Senator Short's speech made eloquently clear was that the Opposition has no strategy. Let us look at the way in which the Opposition's last great advocate of this issue dealt with this matter. I refer to the former shadow Minister for privatisation, Mr Moore. Did he not make a wonderful declaration? I must say in Mr Moore's defence that it was a very honest statement. I think he said exactly what it was the Opposition intended to do, and that is why he was sacked. When talking about the Opposition's forthcoming privatisation program, if it won the election, Mr Moore said:
Professionals in Australia are really looking at the greatest Christmas party they have ever had.
I am sure that that would have been true. He went on to say how the Opposition intended to do this. He used Qantas as an example:
You'd get one of the 767s and a couple of executives, and some sort of video presentation and a couple of good-looking hostesses-
he is as sexist as Senator Short was in his speech-

. . . and you would take this plane to Mt Isa and Darwin and God knows what . . . and take the local identities for a bit of a spin, and give them a spiel, a couple of shots and say, `There's 250,000 shares, and we want you Mr Solicitor, Mr Accountant, Mr Investor to distribute these, and we'll pay you a handling fee'.

He went on in his very open and honest way-but unfortunately for his political career a way that was not very popular with his colleagues because they do not like to talk about these things, for which he was sacked-to say:

. . . banks, brokers, lawyers and accountants at the big end of town will get another shot at the action: providing professional advice and services to the privatisation unit and privatising entities themselves.

In every policy one needs to look at who will lose and who will benefit. In this policy it is very clear who will benefit-those at the top end of town, the professionals, and a few people who think that they can get some very big fat fees out of it.

There has been a long standing commitment-it used to be bipartisan-to the mixed economy. Senator Short did not refer to it. He talked about the inherent superior efficiency of the private sector. Although he did not produce any evidence of it whatsoever, he asserted that that argument had been had and won and that therefore he did not have to bother about it, and he did not.

No issue has been raised-not by Mr Moore, not by Mr Warwick Smith, the now shadow Minister, not by Senator Short and not by Dr Hewson-about the criteria that determine where we draw the line between the public and the private sector and why it is that enterprise A should be private and enterprise B should be public. Not a scintilla of intellectual rigour can be found.

We all know-although we do not all own up to it because it is not convenient if we want to say that everything ought to be is privatised-that there are very significant problems with market failure. There are known, longstanding and established grounds in every economic text book beyond Economics I, which talks about the wonderful neo-classical model as if it might actually exist. That does not always mean that the appropriate response to market failure is public ownership; I am not saying that it does. I am simply saying that we know that there is a very profound question of market failure in Australia as elsewhere and that governments need to be aware of that. People should not believe that first year text books in economics draw a model which, if it were true, would be wonderful.

There are problems about monopoly, the imperfect market and externalities. There is the problem of the short time frame that often necessarily drives private investment decisions. That is not a criticism. It is often the very necessary raison d'etre of that private investment, but it is not always most appropriate for investment in areas such as infrastructure. There are problems of information. Perfect competitive models depend upon the presumption that perfect information will be available. Of course, that is very rarely the case. Sometimes it is dramatically not the case in ways that are significant and profound for the interests of consumers.

I want to contrast this Government's position with that of the Opposition's. The Government has often had to face up to the question of the appropriate balance, about where the line between the private and public sector should be drawn. This Government has appropriately made a large number of decisions-decisions which have never been faced up to before. It has not built a fence around the public sector and said, `What is must always remain'. Neither has it said, `There is no case for the public sector'. Rather, it has said that it is a matter for proper rigorous analysis, appropriate balance and sometimes action, where appropriate, when something is in the national interest; not where it is driven by a fire sale mentality of people desperate to try to paper over certain appalling Budget gaps.
The Government has a view that the Commonwealth Bank should remain in perpetuity in majority government ownership. Actually, that will not be debated next Monday; it is not on the agenda.
