I am not sure that it is a matter of urgency; I am not sure that we really need to sit around here for two hours debating it. But if we were to do so, it would be substantially better than the debate on this rather stupid urgency motion before us. The important issues here are: what is the appropriate balance in a mixed economy; how do we set priorities and make choices in tough economic times? Nothing from the Opposition has ever addressed that question. The luxury of opposition means that one does not have to. That is all right. May those opposite continue to enjoy that luxury; I understand.

Certainly, there are tough decisions to be made. Happily, I am prepared to say, with absolute confidence, that nobody on Monday will be the slightest bit influenced by anything that is said by anybody in the Opposition, nor should they be either on the basis of objective merit, the weight of the argument or the source of the argument. Nothing will be aided by the vapid and the sort of pseudo-urgent arguments and the cheap stunts that we heard and witnessed today.

There are important questions about economic policy. There is the question of the future of the public sector. The way that investment is made in those things which remain in the public sector and in infrastructure is important. The way that we determine which of the existing public sector enterprises may not need to stay in public ownership is important. But it is about rigorous intellectual analysis of the criteria and what determines this. I have yet to hear one word from the Opposition about the criteria that determine what should or should not be in the public sector. All I have heard, without a scintilla of evidence, is that there is a library of argument that asserts this to be so and that Mr Gorbachev says that it is so. That, in itself, is not the world's most persuasive argument. The balance of academic argument does not inherently point in that direction. Sometimes it does, and those matters should be solved; sometimes it does not, and those matters should not.
I am very confident that the Senate will reject this urgency motion and, in so doing, it will treat it with the contempt it deserves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator Spindler, I am sure I do not need to remind honourable senators that under Standing Orders they may interject only with the indulgence of the Chair and when occupying their own seats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are being asked to endorse the selling of shares in the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines Ltd as a necessary precondition to achieving improved efficiency and greater competition. Once again, we are told that this will result in greater efficiency.

SPEECH.PARA: I was a little surprised to hear Senator McMullan saying that his Party will oppose this motion. I know that it is against Australian Labor Party policy. But it is not against what Senator McMullan, and particularly what his Treasurer (Mr Keating), have been saying in the last weeks and months. So I am a little surprised. I wonder how Senator McMullan will get out of that quandary. On balance, I will leave him to the mercy of his members at Monday's conference. Maybe they will assist him to resolve the quandary that he finds himself in.

Today's urgency motion was put forward by Senator Short. It is rather an ideological position but not one that is supported by a lot of rational thinking and rational argument. We are being asked to assume that private enterprise is necessarily efficient. We are being asked to assume that public enterprise is necessarily inefficient. It follows that all employees in private enterprise are wonderful and efficient, whereas employees in public enterprise are badly organised, lazy and so on. That is not only an extremely offensive proposition but also incorrect.

Perhaps Senator Short is not aware of the results put forward by OTC Ltd which were documented in a recent Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) study that quite clearly stated that the cheapest international telephone service in the world is being provided not by a private enterprise company but by OTC, which is a well run publicly owned enterprise. It should be clear that efficiency is a function of management, not an ownership problem. Yet we find that the Opposition's policy document on deregulation and privatisation states:
Privatisation, because it increases competition, will lead to services for consumers which are cheaper, more efficient cost and which provide a wider choice.

Senator Short points to volumes in the library which attest to that particular proposition. I wonder if the gold lettering on the spines of those volumes reads: Bond, Skase, Connell, Herscu, Lowy-all exponents of efficient and successful private management.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the Labor Party membership you were reading out?
—No, the Liberal Party.

—I would suggest, mainly your backers, donors and proteges. Secondly, we are being asked to assume that competition necessarily always produces efficiency. Very clearly, competition is useful in some cases but certainly it is not essential. I cite again OTC and I again cite the State Electricity Commission of Victoria, which, as I have said before, has improved its efficiency, has shed 3,000 workers in the recent six months and is now able to provide electricity to Victorian citizens at a cost which is increasing at a rate well below the increases in the consumer price index. Privatisation is certainly not essential in all enterprises and in some it would be more costly. Certainly, duplication of capital investment, such as involved in Telecom Australia, would be disadvantageous.

SPEECH.PARA: Thirdly, I would like to advert to the corporate culture which in many cases, even if we have competition, produces the opposite result. Let us look at what happened to the influx of foreign banks. What sort of benefits did customers of banks-the borrowers-actually get in our banking sector from the influx of foreign banks? We have had an unprecedented level of interest rates. We have had services reduced to consumers and we have had other services for which consumers are being charged. Competition in the banking sector has not led to greater efficiency.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short is not interested in the evidence.

—I believe that. Senator Short says that there is a big library. I would like to hear in Senator Short's next speech some of the evidence he referred to but has not cited so far. As we are talking about the banking sector, perhaps we should advert to the Commonwealth Bank, founded by King O'Malley, as the people's bank. He would turn in his grave if he heard of Senator McMullan's decision to sell 30 per cent of it to the usurers. In its 1988-89 annual report, the Commonwealth Bank showed that it produced a 14 per cent return on average equity capital employed, which is well in excess of results turned in by the private banking sector. In addition, it paid a dividend of $110m-not small bickies and something that was achieved with good management. Yet, we want to throw that organisation into private competition with a sector which is performing more poorly than that.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at an example. If I own a block of flats and I find that the manager is not producing results or if that investment needs additional capital, I look at improvement to the management, I sack the manager and get somebody else, I borrow money or, if the returns are there, I do not sell the block of flats. Yet that is what we are being asked to do. We also need to look at why we should sell an enterprise that is producing adequate financial returns. We are being asked to sell a stream of dividends which is likely to give a return for years to come to the community as a whole. We are being asked to sell it at today's prices, at garage sale prices, to retire a debt in nominal terms at an interest rate which will not return, on the basis of the performance of the Commonwealth Bank, anything like the benefits that the community can expect to derive from its property.

I now advert to another reason which I noted Senator Short has not addressed at all: the community service obligations of enterprises which we are supposed to endorse to be sold off for the not proven efficiency and competition reasons. I mention just one that was not adverted to today: the National Acoustic Laboratories Hearing Centres, which are ready for the auction block. It has been shown quite clearly that some of the services-the assessment of children with hearing impairment-will not be carried out by anyone who is running the acoustic laboratory on a profit basis.

Let me return once again to the Commonwealth Bank situation. I had occasion earlier this week to ask the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), who represents the Treasurer (Mr Keating): Who will take care of the community service obligation of the Commonwealth Bank and will he ensure that they will be met? The Minister's answer was to categorise them as commercial decisions, rather than as community service obligations. I repeat that question: who will actually supply bank statements in braille? Clearly that is not a commercial decision. Very clearly that service will not turn a profit. Therefore, will we retain them or will we throw them away?

The Opposition's position is to sell not only the airlines and the Commonwealth Bank but also OTC, Telecom, Medibank Private, Australian National Line, the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation plus many other government enterprises. In addition, it also agrees with the Government's proposals to sell the Sydney-Moomba gas pipeline, the Housing Loans Insurance Commission and Aussat.

But why stop there? Why not privatise the Reserve Bank of Australia, the Australian National Museum or even Antarctica? Could I suggest that, if the Government is serious about the propositions it is putting forward, it might consider putting Mr Skase and Mr Lowy in charge of a totally privatised communications industry? What about Mr Bond in charge of a privatised navy in pursuit of the Iraqi cup? What about Mr Elliott in charge of a privatised Victorian health promotion foundation with particular responsibility to raise funds from the consumption of alcohol? What about Mr Connell being placed in charge of a privatised social security investment advice unit for pensioners? And so on. I have yet to see a cogently argued position by either the Opposition parties or the Government as the Government is doing its current back flip.

Let me advert to one other aspect which was brought up by Barry Jones and Duncan Kerr. They have proposed that we have a wealth inquiry to show clearly why the current trend towards the poor getting poorer and the rich getting richer is happening. One of the factors they have identified is that privatisation will merely increase the skewed distribution of wealth in Australia: the 8 per cent of the community who are shareholders get the privilege of gilt edged investments and the other 92 per cent of the population get nothing except fewer services and higher bills.

Finally, I would like to ask honourable senators: Do we really want to live in a society where every decision is made on the basis of dollars and cents, where every decision that adverts to social or cultural values is reduced to a balance sheet mentality without any concern for human values? I mention the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Commission, which is another item that is on the auction block. At this stage we are only taking one step towards it. It is being corporatised and turned into a company limited by shares. What is to stop a future treasurer, or even this Treasurer, ringing the management and the directors of that company and saying, `Let us place 30 per cent, 40 per cent, or 60 per cent of your shares on the stock exchange.'?

Let me then ask honourable senators who may have a relative or close family member suffering from a disease that requires a particular serum what they would think if such a laboratory decided that since there were only about 100 cases in Australia the serum was not profitable and questioned why it should engage in research for medication that affects so few people. No doubt such a laboratory would instead engage in the production of the next edition of aspirin. That would have hundreds of thousands of users but, if there is a serum that addresses a particular complaint suffered by only a few people, one would think that a civilised and humane society would ensure that these people were given help.

The principle that because something is not profitable help cannot be provided is the very position that we are being asked to endorse. It is not too late for the Labor Government to reverse its direction; it is not too late for Senator Short to provide evidence for his position. Why should the richest in our society set the agenda? The only reason these measures will succeed is the rigidity of the Australian party political system. I suggest to the Australian Labor Party that it consider a conscience vote on the privatisation proposals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me respond to some comments made by Senator McMullan. I am pleased that at least we have a Minister sitting in the chamber at the moment, although no Minister will be participating in this debate-a very important debate about the future economic direction of this country. Senator McMullan said that he saw no reason why the Senate should have the opportunity to endorse Senator Short's motion. As elected members of the House of the people of Australia, we are more entitled to be debating a motion such as this, seeking endorsement, than the Australian Labor Party conference will be next Monday. We are at least elected representatives of the people of Australia. The conference next week will not be representative of the elected people of Australia. The position is that we are far more entitled to be making that judgment than the conference will be.

SPEECH.PARA: We have the spectacle of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), duly elected for a three-year term, having to get on the telephone to ring around to 101 people in this country asking them whether as the elected Prime Minister he can pursue a policy direction that he and his Cabinet know is right for the people and the economy of Australia. What a debacle. What a situation when the duly elected Prime Minister has to make phone calls all around the country before he can pursue a policy line that is right for the people of Australia.

I wish also to comment on the reference to examples. It has been asked, `Where are the examples of the efficiency of the private sector over that of the government sector?'. There are numerous such examples, but two come to mind readily. In South Australia, for example, at a time when we were closing hospital wards because of a lack of funds, the State Government was injecting $6 billion of taxpayers' money into buying tumble driers for the clothing factory, the laundry. Where are the priorities of government in that instance? In Queensland the private sector looks after our prisons, our correctional institutions, at a far cheaper rate than any government instrumentality can do in any State in Australia.

They are the priorities that are being put in place to save taxpayers' dollars so they can be put into the area of the provision of essential services for people-education, health, and the like. We need to get back to the priorities of government expenditure. Government enterprises in many States in Australia lost a total of $2 billion in the course of the last financial year. That money ought to be directed to the areas of priority for which governments are elected-the provision of essential services for people. It should not be out in the marketplace competing unfairly, unjustly and unreasonably. Taxpayers dollars are not collected to do that; they are there to provide essential services for people. It is about time we got those priorities right.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I am sure that you will understand, as do my colleagues, that it gives me a lot of pleasure to participate in the debate on this urgency motion today. Five years down the track, I might happen to have the last laugh. Having put privatisation on the Australian political agenda in 1985 in the lead-up to and during the South Australian election campaign, nothing gives me greater pleasure in 1990 than to see that stance, that core of political philosophy, starting to be vindicated right across the political spectrum. It seems right that I am in Canberra, in the Senate, to witness what through those years has been a policy embraced and about to be acted on by my opposition, a Labor Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ones that opposed you.

—The ones that opposed it-and, what is more, led by none other than Mr Hawke and the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the very men who in 1985 called privatisation a `vandalistic splurge' and a `disastrous experiment'. The scare campaign which Keating and Hawke ran with such fervour against privatisation in 1985 undoubtedly cost my Party seats in that State election campaign. So there has been naturally for me an added pleasure in watching the Labor Party squirm, duck and weave over the crucial issue of selling shares in government instrumentalities such as the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines Ltd, and its contortions over Telecom Australia. There is, of course, also additional anger about the many years over which the Australian public and the Australian economy have been deprived of the benefits of such sales as policy because of the intransigent view and stance of the Labor Party until now. While I am sure that there are many in the community shocked at the stark turnaround in political philosophy that we have seen from the Prime Minister and his Deputy, I for one am gratified that they have at last so publicly admitted the correctness of the policy direction and the error of their ways of the past. At the same time, it does not do to dwell on how many other Liberal policies they have ridiculed over the years which ought to be in place and which we could have benefited from.

SPEECH.PARA: In the meantime, I certainly welcome the Labor Party's change of stance on an issue so essential to the future of the Australian economy. Make no mistake about it; it is essential. We are a nation in trouble, and it is to be hoped that what the Labor Party decides on as its brand of privatisation next Monday will not be far too little, too late. We should take this opportunity to welcome the Labor Party to the real world of twentieth century politics, where it is patently wrong to cling to old values and outmoded philosophies, of which public ownership is most obviously one.

In 1990, being anti-privatisation is so outmoded that even Mikhail Gorbachev has spurned it for Russia, saying succinctly last month, 'We'll be phasing out state property'. In Russia private farming plots that are being converted from communal plots are becoming 40 times more efficient as soon as the private people have responsibility for production on that land.

Let us look at the area of housing. Fidel Castro is privatising public housing in Cuba, as is Margaret Thatcher in the United Kingdom. If public housing is being privatised in such political extremes as Cuba and the United Kingdom, why are we not doing it here in Australia? Why are we not giving citizens who over their whole lifetimes have been paying rent for public housing the opportunity to buy that housing for themselves? That is where the policy direction has been wrong in the past and that is why it needs changing. That is why privatisation is the right policy direction for the future of this country and for individuals, the people whom the Australian Democrats supposedly stand up for.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they are just the left wing of the Labor Party.

—We have seen that time and time again. We had from the Democrats the analogy of a block of flats-that one would not sell a block of flats just because it was not going well. They seem to misunderstand that the private sector has a discipline. It is called 30 June. If one has not made a profit by 30 June one does not stay in business. So there is a discipline-a discipline to manage properly and efficiently.

SPEECH.PARA: But in the government sector if an organisation does not happen to make it by 30 June it is not sold up; it gets another injection of taxpayers' funds to keep it rolling on for another year. There is no discipline in the government sector such as we have in the private sector. That is the very real and fundamental difference between the two philosophical stances and policy directions.

That is why, with $2m of taxpayers' funds down the drain already over the course of the last year or so, we need to rethink that policy direction. Particularly with taxes so high, as they are in this country, if we are going to relieve the burden on all ordinary Australians, we need to get the policy direction right. That policy direction means looking after and providing essential services for people, and getting out of the way, off the back of and not competing unfairly with the private sector.

If Russia can recognise that clinging to history is no way to tackle a competitive and difficult economic future, what has taken Australia's Labor Party so long to accept the inevitable? It is unfortunate that, in all the emotion of the Government's sell-off decision making and its most public factional pain at the reversal of policy, what privatisation brings to our economy has, unfortunately, largely been forgotten. Put simply, it revitalises it. It cannot be denied that Australia is one of the last major industrialised economies in the world to recognise and act on that fact.

Most other governments have accepted, long before Australia, that it is government's role not to provide all services but, instead, to ensure that they are provided. To honour social justice obligations, governments obviously must provide those essential services, and with excellence. But, most importantly, they should then get out of the service arena, get off the agenda of service providing in that area. That is central to achieving a lean and efficient public sector, and it is essential to remove the tax burden from all and ordinary Australians. Government must be freed from the burdens of running businesses which belong in private hands.

It is not enough that governments ensure that the private sector provides all but the essential services. After all, not even Labor's left wing has a valid argument against the fact that private companies operating in competition operate more efficiently, more productively, and provide far better service to consumers than do public enterprises.

TALK.START.PARA: —A spectacular foreign debt.

—Listen to the Democrats going on. They have had their opportunity to participate in this debate and they have not put up one logical argument against the move that this motion asks the Senate to support in terms of privatisation of these major instrumentalities. On the other hand, public monopolies have a well-recognised tendency to entrench inefficiencies and to foster the wasteful misallocation of increasingly scarce public resources.

SPEECH.PARA: Take Telecom as a glaring example of why privatisation is necessary for the good of the public purse. Its inability to satisfy customer demands or to deal with customer complaints is legendary. Telecom is ranked by Australian business people as the worst public utility in terms of repairs, performance and responsiveness to customers. As well, its lack of productivity is set out in figures which indicate that it has 60 per cent more employees per unit of service than 12 other leading telephone enterprises around the world. It has been estimated that competitive reforms would save users at least 15 per cent of their present costs, some $1,050m a year.

As for the airlines, it only takes a look at the global picture to see that just six of the world's largest airlines out of a total of 35 remain government owned. Even if the Government wants to own airlines, the taxpayers of Australia simply cannot afford it. We cannot, for example, sit back and watch Qantas, without doubt one of the world's best airlines, deteriorate to a second-rate operation with outmoded equipment and planes-which it will do without a massive injection of capital, capital which we do not have without the involvement of private enterprise. Where do the taxpayers of Australia find ways to deal with company debt of $3 billion and the need to inject more than $1 billion a year? The Government is in no economic position to continue supporting Qantas.

After all, we already have a foreign debt level so crippling that it takes the equivalent of $250 from each household in Australia each month just to pay the interest on it. We cannot pay our way as it is, and yet the Democrats are suggesting that we ought to compound the problem with their policy direction. There is simply no public money for capital injection into Qantas. Similarly, Australian Airlines needs $4 billion if it is to upgrade and compete successfully after deregulation. In other words, it needs a capital base unavailable to it as a government owned operation.
Looking at the airline problems, there is a quote which stays in my mind from 1985, when from the sayings of Paul Keating came the following:

The Labor Party will fight tooth and nail to keep these public authorities in the hands of the Commonwealth. We are about refurbishing them and keeping them strong. We are not about wrecking them and selling them. The great public services they provide will continue to be provided while ever this Government has the breath to defend them.

It is ironic, is it not, especially when considering the airlines, that what has happened is exactly the opposite of those words of but five years ago. Australia cannot afford to refurbish them. To keep them public would be to wreck them. To sell them is to make them strong. Life and politics have moved on. It is therefore to be hoped that next Monday's Labor privatisation conference will ratify the Prime Minister's most sensible desire to sell off all of Australian Airlines and 49 per cent of Qantas. I hope he is successful in achieving that aim. Selling anything less than all of Australian Airlines would be to further cripple the public purse.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —When a motion of urgency comes before this chamber, I think it is reasonable to expect that it will outline a coherent strategy: this one does not. As a matter of fact, nothing could better illustrate the bankruptcy opposite in this chamber than the proposition that is before us. The very fact that it appears is reflective of the bankrupt estate in the conservatives' ranks. Nothing could better underline the sterility in the ranks of the coalition, the lack of alternative policies or, indeed, the lack even of an alternative political framework-but, most of all, the lack of an alternative vision.
—We used to have alternative policies when you opposed privatisation. But now you are in favour of it we have the same.

—Senator, the policy credit rating of those opposite is about as high as Christopher Skase's financial credit rating. The Liberal and National parties are showing all the classic signs of having been too long in opposition-a situation they are likely to occupy for much longer-and are showing the frustrations and the obvious disappointments. This is now reflected in an essentially negative approach to politics. It is very much like the Australian Labor Party in the 1950s and 1960s. The coalition simply reacts to the agenda that the Labor Government establishes. It reacts to determinations of the Government. Ministers now even take questions in this chamber about the determinations of the Caucus of the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party. Honourable senators opposite have no alternative view-none whatsoever. All we hear are absolute platitudes and slogans.

SPEECH.PARA: If we ask what the coalition would do, there are a few reasonable guides. We could look at recent history, at the coalition's own words. We could look at the Fraser years from 1975 to 1983. We could look at Mr Moore, as Senator McMullan did a little earlier. We could look at the experience of the only conservative government at a State level, the GreinerMurray Government, or we can look at the slogans on privatisation. I turn to the Fraser years, and for this I am indebted to my colleague Senator Walsh for his analysis in the Australian Financial Review. He said that the Fraser years may best be judged on two essential criteria, the macro-economic performance as reflected in Budgets and its approach on micro-economic issues. I think they are fair criteria on which to judge the Fraser years. On expenditure, for example, six of seven Fraser Budgets increased expenditure as a proportion of gross domestic product (GDP); that is the record of those opposite.

To 1982-83-the last Fraser-Howard Budget-expenditure had reached 28.9 per cent as a proportion of GDP; compared with the previous Labor Budget of 1975 when it was 24.1 per cent of GDP; or compared with the current Budget of the Hawke Government when it is 23.7 per cent of GDP. That is a fair contrast. In 1987 under the Labor Government, the Budget moved into surplus for the first time since 1953-something the coalition was never able to do; it was not even able to approach that in the most remote manner.

There was no coalition performance at all in terms of an macro-economic basis and no performance at all in terms of electoral responsibility. Virtually everything the Fraser Government did was electorally driven. It was all targeted upon the very next election-all predicated on votes-as seen in 1981 when Treasury Secretary, John Stone, was actually applauding the blow-out in imports. The 1980 election was the hurdle he had in mind.

The coalition had absolutely no performance in micro-economic reform. It is a pity it did not show some sense of urgency when it was in government. Let us look at the record of micro-economic reform when the coalition was in government. Consistently, determinations were made that inhibited or prohibited the process: the reaffirmation of the two-airline agreement and increasing tariffs, including those on passenger motor vehicles. There was no labour market reform whatsoever-not even attempted. There was no reform in the ports or in shipping. None in the maritime industries at all. Look how the Opposition has gone silent when its record is examined. Look how it is absolutely silent. There was no tax reform and there was no financial deregulation. That was the coalition's record.

Compare that with the record of the Hawke Government which is outstanding, because it happens to be built upon a strategy. For example, there is a three-year program for waterfront reform, to close the competitive gap between the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) and our maritime industries, leading to a reduction in the work force of 20 per cent by 1992. By 1992 the average crew level in Australian ships will be that of the OECD. Already there has been a reduction of 25 per cent in the work force. There are 13 ships on the Australian coast already operating under the rationalised strategy adopted by the Maritime Industries Development Committee.

The Shipping Industry Reform Authority is developing further efficiencies cooperatively with the ACTU, the relevant unions and the relevant business enterprises. That is an important distinction between the coalition and the Government-a process of cooperation against a process of confrontation.

The Trade Practices Commission is active in the ports of Sydney, Newcastle, Botany Bay and Melbourne. There is waterfront reform in three areas. There is restructuring in stevedoring, Federal-State consultations on interfacing between road transport and the waterfront, and the Prices Surveillance Authority has also been active.

When in government the coalition had absolutely no performance to speak of on micro-economic reform, including the two years when it had absolute majorities in both Houses of this Parliament; when Malcolm Fraser, to use Billy Hughes's classic expression, could have put pen to paper and written the law of the Commonwealth of Australia, and nothing happened. Let me refer to something that is perhaps a little more contemporary than the Fraser years. I refer to an article in the Business Review Weekly dated 23 February 1990 in which John Moore outlined the coalition's policy on micro-economic reform. Two quotes will suffice to show what the coalition was about. The first states:
Professionals are in for a bonanza if the coalition wins the March 24 federal election. Accountants, lawyers and stockbrokers all stand to make big gains in their fee income . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the second time it has been recycled.
—Because it is worth repeating. It is worth driving the nail home. The article continues:

SPEECH.PARA: `Professionals in Australia are really looking at the greatest Christmas party they've ever had,' says Opposition privatisation spokesman John Moore.
He should have stuck to Four Corners-he was better.

TALK.START.PARA: —You read that better than the previous bloke.
—With greater emphasis.
—Is this your privatisation speech for Monday?
—Order! Senator Crane, I advise you that if you wish to interject you have to do so from your own seat.

—Regarding the airlines, as Senator McMullan made clear, there was the sexist reference to having the good-looking hostesses off to one side to help sell the public assets. That begs the question of who would benefit under the conservative's policy. Not ordinary Australians for a moment. Certainly not working people. They do not even figure in the coalition's thinking-not for a moment. They never have and they never will.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the national interest, the policies of the Labor Government are the policies to follow. In terms of the special interest, it is the policies of the coalition. Those close to the conservatives can always expect to benefit.

The reality of the Government's initiative on the Commonwealth Bank of Australia is that that decision has been taken. It was taken by the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party Caucus on a recommendation from the Treasurer. Senator Short is simply wrong to say it is on the agenda for next Monday. I presided over the meeting of the National Executive of the Australian Labor Party at which the resolution to which Senator Short has been referring was adopted, and the Commonwealth Bank is not contained therein. It has been decided.

As to the `faceless men' remark-how on earth can a conference that is probably going to be broadcast live, if not telecast live by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, be said to be faceless with several hundred media present not only from Australia but also internationally?

The problem that the coalition has-particularly the Liberal Party-is that our conferences actually mean something. They make determinations that mean something. They have a democratic function. They are part of the political process. It is going to be a great honour to preside over the conference next Monday. The problem Senator Short has is that of contrasting our conferences, which are part of a democratic process-that actually have a function and a series of democratic objectives-with the Liberal Party conferences, where all of note is John Elliott swaggering around like some Antipodean Emperor Jones. The coalition's conferences mean nought. That is the great contrast. Our conference is a serious policy forum and its decisions matter. There is no greater indictment of the Opposition than the observations that Laurie Oakes made in today's Bulletin.

TALK.START.PARA: —How does it say the Prime Minister is going?
—I thank Senator Short for inviting me to quote it. I shall. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister has prepared a paper on ways to improve proceedings in the House of Representatives, and discussed it with Liberal leader John Hewson. The proposals include the introduction of electronic voting and rostering ministers for Question Time. Having watched the way Parliament has operated in recent weeks, I have a suggestion for more fundamental reform. It seems to me it would be a good idea to have a group of MPs, designated 'The Opposition,' whose role would be to ask probing questions, expose the government's shortcomings and attack it when it makes mistakes. Hawke, however, might find it difficult to get Hewson's agreement for such a change.

One could say the same about this proposition before the chamber today. Just look at the record of the coalition in government and in Opposition, through Mr Moore; or the Greiner-Murray Government, where a surplus of $34m announced by a Premier and Treasurer that actually turns out to be a deficit of some $600m. That is really creative accounting. That is worthy of Qintex Australia. Micro-economic reform for the Greiner-Murray Government has been nothing other than redundancies for working people. The burden has fallen in total on working people.

In terms of micro-economic reform, and industrial relations in this country, we have taken a great many restrictions out of the workplace already. We have a wages policy, which the coalition lacks. The coalition is utterly bankrupt of a wages policy. TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of this debate is simply to allow the elected representatives of Australia to signify, in the very clearest of terms, that it is in the interests of the nation that shares in Australian Airlines Ltd, Qantas Airways Ltd and the Commonwealth Bank of Australia be sold. SPEECH.PARA: We do not particularly expect the Australian Democrats to do it because we know that they are adopting the cheap political tactic of trying to pick up the votes of the 10 or 12 per cent of people in Australia who still believe in these old socialist views. The Democrats are trying to capture that end of the market so that their current fairly poor vote might get a little bit better and they might get a few extra per cent.

But we are hoping that the Australian Labor Party (ALP) will use this debate to signify clearly its support for privatisation of Australian Airlines, Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank. It is very clear that the majority of Australians believe in this and genuinely want the efficiency and competition that privatisation will bring.

Privatisation was a key plank in the coalition's Economic Action Plan at the last election, a plan which was endorsed by over 50 per cent of Australians quite deliberately, as was shown in the election result. This policy was enunciated very particularly in terms which would have seen privatised, among other things, the two airlines and the bank.

Our policy took into account the fact that rates of return on the capital invested in public trading enterprises are significantly lower than those in the corporate trading sector. Resources are thus inefficiently tied up in public enterprises, predominantly in the areas of transport and communication. When such essential services are not provided in the most efficient manner, Australian businesses and households suffer through higher prices and inadequate standards of service.

A privatisation program should be motivated by principles that there should be a clear benefit to the consumer taxpayer, that the employees should be offered the option of buying shares in the enterprise on a preferential basis, that the quality and availability of the service is maintained to remote areas, that the program be carried out gradually with a thorough investigation of the options, and that monopoly rights of the enterprise should not be maintained in order to enhance the sale price.

At the last election our privatisation proposals were opposed by the ALP. It appears that the policies of the ALP were then the plaything of non-elected representatives who had no idea of what was best for Australia. We affirm our opposition to privatisation in all of its forms. We know that this opposition is shared throughout the whole of the Labor movement.

What in the name of reason is the justification for breaking up and selling off the great and efficient national enterprises, like the Commonwealth Bank, Telecom, TAA and Qantas?

But since the election there has been overwhelming support from the Government side for privatisation, as the Government struggles from economic crisis to economic crisis, to such an extent that the Government has now found that Australia's future depends on micro-economic reform, which includes the efficiency and competition that privatisation will bring.

Now we have the Prime Minister, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and most of their Cabinet colleagues, including the front bench in this chamber, roundly supporting privatisation. What a turnaround by the Prime Minister, when he said in July of this year:
They-
referring to the ALP-

have got to ask themselves whether it is the best use of scarce resources to fund airlines, which means if you do that, there's less funds available to fund obligations towards private citizens . . . . .

Now we even have the Premier of Queensland, Mr Goss, who is not renowned for making any decisions at all, coming out today in support of the Beazley Clayton's privatisation proposal for Telecom, saying that the competition would do a lot of good. The massive injection of funds that are needed to enable Qantas and Australian Airlines, for example, to compete on equal terms in a very competitive market requires funds, as Mr Hawke said, that Australia simply does not have.

The case for privatisation, with the improved efficiency and greater competition it brings, is clearly understood amongst the economists, business leaders and elected representatives of this nation; it is understood by most of the front bench senators of this chamber. It is important that we take this opportunity today to express, in the clearest terms, our support as elected representatives for the sale of shares in these government businesses. It must be done as a matter of urgency because this is on the eve of a conference being called by people not elected by Australians, at which they will try to force their minority view on the elected Parliament of this nation. The people who are leading the charge against privatisation are, of course, the union bosses who are not elected by the Australian public or, if the Cooke inquiry is to be believed, by too many other people either. The union bosses do not want privatisation, because they understand that privatisation would involve better relationships between the managers and the workers and it would involve profit sharing, which means workers getting part of the dividends and profits that would result from the efficiency and productivity of privatisation. If the workers are part owners of these businesses-this is proposed in our policy and I understand that it is part of the policy being proposed by the right wing of the Labor Party-then what is left for the unions? It is quite simple that in these instances the union bosses would be without a job. So it is really a matter of saving their empires.

Mr McLean, the Queensland President of the ALP and one of the leading unionists in the telecommunications industry, has led the charge against privatisation and deregulation because he knows that the power now held by people like him would diminish enormously if Telecom were privatised. He has examples of that with Metway Bank Ltd and Power Brewing because he realises that the unions become irrelevant.

Mr McLean talks of the Party being railroaded on privatisation by Cabinet. He says that `government initiatives are increasingly coming from bureaucrats and textbook economists instead of the rank and file'. If this is true, then this is one occasion that Australia can say, `Thank heavens for the bureaucrats and textbook economists'.

This Government should be governing from this Parliament, not from some conference room where matters are being dealt with by non-elected people. These backroom operators, these unelected power brokers, these faceless men are not elected by anyone at all but they are going to try to tell the Government's elected representatives what they should do. These people want to tell the Government that it cannot do what it knows to be the best for Australia.

This urgency motion was brought on today to give Government members the opportunity of having the support so that they can go to their conference shored up with some backbone. It is urgent and has to be dealt with today to give the Government a bit of backbone, which it does not seem to have, to make the decision. The Government cannot make the decision in Parliament; it has to run down the road and beg other people for permission to do what it knows is right. That is what this debate is all about. The Opposition is trying to help the Government. For once the Government has done the right thing. The Australian Democrats will not do it, because they are trying to get the cheap votes that the Government used to get. The Opposition is trying to give the Government the support that will allow it to go ahead and privatise. SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators opposite ought to understand that the forums of the Australian Labor Party are the most open of any political party of Australia. I start with beef. I am concerned that there is the danger that the European Community might break its agreement not to release subsidised beef into Pacific Rim markets. This would have a terrible consequence for Australian primary producers.

I also note that we still seem to have substantial levels of subsidy in the European Community when it comes to beef. From figures available to me it appears that there is still a 25 per cent difference between the administered price and the producer price for beef in 12 European Community countries. This raises a matter of grave concern, which is: What are we, as a nation, doing when it comes to trade negotiations? I have had a number of discussions with various people, including at least one ambassador.

Those discussions have highlighted one fact and one fact very clearly-that the other primary producing nations of the world look upon Australia as a leader in trade negotiations. Those primary producing countries looked with a sense of dismay at the Government's approach to the Uruguay Round of trade negotiations, in which the Government went in, having made unilateral reductions in the level of tariffs, with the consequence that we did not have any bargaining chips.

I know for a fact that at least one ambassador went to the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Dr Blewett) and begged him not to go into the Uruguay Round, having made those unilateral reductions. If, as a consequence of that, we suffer particular problems with tariffs and continuing European Community subsidies, the Government will have to bear the condemnation of primary producers.

I also address the matter of mutton and live sheep exports. That is also of importance. Last year we saw a reduction in the value to this country of live sheep exports of some $40m as a result of the difficulties in Saudi Arabia. This represents a reduction of 1.6 million head in live sheep exports. I know that some of my Democrat friends would like to see the abolition of the live sheep export trade, but I do not believe that this is in the best interests of primary producers. It is a matter of some concern.

Although Iran recently signed a contract which committed it to purchase another 24,000 tonnes of mutton, we must look upon the Middle East market as essentially unstable. There is still work that can be done to improve the standard of coverage by Australian entities in the Middle East and to improve the prospects of our exports being accepted over there.

We also have problems in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. At the moment its grain surplus is expected to be used as feed for beef. Therefore, this means a reduction in the Russian demand for beef, which is currently 200,000 tonnes a year. Although Russia is not a substantial importer from Australia, this will have consequences for the market. It will therefore have consequences for Australian primary producers.

Very clearly one of the problems that Australian primary producers face is the high dollar, which is impeding access to markets and the cost-effectiveness and competitiveness of Australian primary producers. That area is within the realms of this Government's work. It is the consequence of this Government's handiwork.

It does not seem as though the country task force of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is doing much for primary producers. It has failed to convey to this Government the concern of primary producers from one end of this country to the other, and the consequence that the very high level of the Australian dollar is having not only on their personal incomes but also on the income of the Australian economy as a whole.

I also point out to the chamber the significance of the comments on page 28 about transport. We need to have substantial reform of the waterfront. The comments that shipping and aviation transport costs amount to 20 per cent of the landed costs of some Australian primary produce are very important. I am very concerned. We need to see substantial and real improvements on waterfront reform.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations was, as the title of its first report states, seeking to find ways to balance control and compassion when dealing with the problem of illegal entrants. It is an emotional minefield and for some it has become a political battlefield. But neither of those points gives any politician the right to walk away from the decisions which will be considered by some sections to be unyielding and unpopular.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has been charged with finding ways to tackle the problem. It is a problem that politicians cannot procrastinate over, cannot ignore, shuffle around or mumble about. The bottom line is that we have more than 100,000 people living in Australia who are doing so illegally. We do know that the majority deliberately broke the rules. They well know they are living here outside the law.

We owe it to every single person who has applied to join us through the proper channels, and who is enduring the long wait for acceptance, to deal once and for all with illegals in a firm but fair manner. Our stand must be a very visible warning to anyone overseas who is contemplating staying behind here on a tourist or student visa-the two most popular methods-that Australia is no longer the lucky country for illegals. And there is absolutely no point in looking tough and then acting softly.

I believe that is what has happened previously and will continue to happen if some of the Committee's recommendations in this first report are accepted. That is why I was party to a dissenting report. Yes, it was certainly difficult, especially during public submissions to the Committee, not to let the heart rule the head on illegals. There were some very compelling arguments put to us. It would have been easy to be swayed by protestations that many illegals have become good and worthy hardworking people making a valuable contribution to our society. I do not doubt they have. But to have been swayed to ignore that these people must remain responsible for the results of their own deliberate and considered actions-no matter what they now contribute-would have been to entrench the perception that Australia does not take our illegals situation seriously.

For that reason also it is inappropriate that the five year absorption principle should be contemplated. That principle is akin to handing over the key to the door. It was on that key point-the absorption principle and the five-year benchmark on 31 October 1985-that I have supported a dissenting report. In other words, illegals get in, stay low, then put up their heads with a job, a family and some character references five years on and we will have a belated welcome home party for them. The absorption principle also indicates to illegals and to others contemplating similar action that they can get away with it if they hang on long enough. It makes a mockery of any rules and regulations and, worse, it makes a mockery of all those who arrive here the right way, often after years of physical hardship or fear from political regimes in their home lands. We owe them the right to become valued citizens far more than we will ever owe it to those who treated our rules and our values with some contempt.

Our migration program must be successful. We need to ensure that Australians accept our migration program as a carefully considered one for the long-term good of our country. We cannot afford to let racist elements damage efforts to make it work by creating a perception that we do not have the fortitude to enforce its rules, or worse that the program has no rules that cannot be broken. In this regard we cannot be seen as weak. But weak we most definitely are if we allow any five-year absorption plan to proceed.

It is simply unbelievable that we will make this five-year absorption amnesty the one and only. That is exactly what has been said, in effect, time and time again. To condone it happening now is to shout to illegals, and to those who protect them, that eventually some more politicians will come along with yet another one and only five-year absorption amnesty; that all they need to do is to stay low for another few years. No-one believes politicians any longer on this issue-and I am talking about a track record of 10 or 20 years-certainly not some groups, albeit a minority, that are not beyond using emotional blackmail and pressure in what is an exceptionally emotional issue.

As I have already stated, my firm view is that our Committee was not set up to make decisions based on emotion or on fear of being unpopular. We must never forget that the long term success of a true multicultural society with the assimilation of many diverse groups rests on a sane, sensible and, most importantly, controlled migration program. That means that it is time to begin treating deliberate illegals as they deserve, in my view, to be treated.

The British model for dealing with illegals makes sense, and I am all in favour of a similar proposal here. I am disappointed that the British model in total-not in part-was not part of the final report. The United Kingdom model operates from the base that deportation will normally be the proper course when someone is found to be illegal. That is the base from which to proceed. It then works back from that line with a list of clearly defined circumstances where exceptions to the deportation rule may be made. It leaves little room for confusion or continual amnesties.

This is what we should be striving for-firmness and fairness, and firmness and fairness which are set out in a way that is easily understood by both those who have to enforce the rules and those who break them. However, the problem is now so entrenched in Australia that we need to tackle it from a wider base. It is time for consideration to be given to strengthening and enforcing legislation which makes it a criminal offence to harbour illegals.

When the Migration Act was revamped late last year we increased the penalties to be imposed under section 80, allowing for fines of $5,000 or two years' imprisonment or both for people who deliberately harboured illegals. That is an increase on the 1985 penalties of a $1,000 fine or six months' gaol, but they still do not appear to be worrying those who are helping illegals. Therefore, they ought to be increased. If a person who is not an Australian citizen is harbouring an illegal, if that person is going to deliberately flout the law in harbouring illegal migrants, his or her right to continue to live in Australia should be put at risk.

They are areas that we need to tackle. Certainly, the legislation needs to be enforced. To date, responsibility for the enforcement of the legislation has generally been piecemeal and penalties have rarely been enforced. That ought to change immediately. It would surely be a first step towards stopping the influx of illegal immigrants and it would signify that we are serious-a message that has not yet been communicated.

Section 80 is such a little-used part of the legislation that it is clear that many illegals and those who support and shelter them feel so confident that they will not be caught and punished that they consider their actions fair game. It is no game, but even we, the politicians, could appear to be treating it as such if we hide from the hard and, yes, unpopular decision relating first to illegals and secondly to those who harbour them within our community. It is time for our actions to spell that out in strict rules and regulations which cannot be misinterpreted or misunderstood. That is the control that our Committee was set up to find ways to deliver.

However, compassion should be directed to the group of innocent illegals in Australia. They ought to be considered, protected and cared for. A determination to deal with deliberate illegals must in no way infringe on our compassionate dealings with those who find themselves illegal through no fault of their own.

We have a case at present which shows all the traumas of such a predicament. It is that of two teenage sisters who have been in Australia since they were months old. Only now, when one is studying hard at university and the other a State public servant, have they realised that they are not Australians; they have no right of residency. We should not be heaping the sins of the parents on the children because the parents are illegal immigrants. These girls are to all intents and purposes Australian, and we ought to treat them as such.

There is another case, that of a teenage boy brought here on a visitor's visa by his grandmother when he was a baby and passed on to an aunt when his grandmother died. He too has only now discovered that his grandmother and his aunt were both illegal immigrants, as he is. I believe from all the evidence that I have heard as a member of the Committee that control and compassion go together, but there is a warning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, I have pleasure in contributing to the debate on the Committee's report Balancing Control and Compassion. It is clear that the neglect of previous governments has left Australia with a legacy of illegal entrants which is estimated at between 90,000 and 150,000. These figures are very large and one wonders how they have reached this size. The answer is simple: they have occurred over a number of years due to a lack of enforcement of compliance procedures. Many illegals currently in Australia have been here for quite some time, although the majority have been here for less than five years.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Standing Committee has addressed the problem of illegal entrants as a priority and put forward a number of measures to deal with those illegals currently in Australia, and it offers recommendations for dealing with illegal immigrants in the future. The Australian Democrats support tough measures to apprehend and deport illegal entrants. This is certainly necessary to protect the integrity of our immigration program, because to the extent that we allow queue jumpers to get away with breaking the law we reduce our capacity to receive refugees and family reunion migrants who are taking their turn in the approval process. The refugee problem, as outlined in the report of the National Population Council, is expected to grow markedly and Australia will become more and more a country of first asylum. We certainly have an obligation to the global community to recognise this and take appropriate action.

I agree with my colleague Senator John Coulter when he says that we should deal with refugees at source and should assist other countries to avoid the sort of conditions-economic, social and political-which cause people to leave their countries as refugees. However, we have an existing problem. There are currently about one million refugees in camps dotted around the South-East Asian region in particular, and we believe that the current provision of 11,000 places for refugees is a niggardly response to the rapidly increasingly numbers. We advocate an increase to 20,000, in line with our continuing policy to give priority to the refugee and family reunion categories.

The Government's attempt last year to codify Australia's immigration laws has produced a rigid and oppressive body of legislation which makes it virtually impossible to take account of individual circumstances where the strict application of the law would produce unjustifiable hardship. The number of categories that individuals can use to apply for entry has been markedly reduced. We therefore have situations occurring where innocent illegals, often children, have no recourse under the legislation as it now stands. One example of this is a Fijian boy, deserted by his mother, who came to Australia with his grandmother on a visitor's permit at the age of five. His grandmother died during the visit and the boy was left staying with his great aunt. Now aged 11, with no immediate family in Fiji and basically having been brought up here, there is no compassionate scope for him to stay in Australia.

This codification of policies into law has been coupled with a tightening of ministerial discretion. The Minister, as a primary decision maker, has now little or no discretion to set aside or act outside the legislative framework. Ministerial discretion is applicable only to those with a domestic right of review. Therefore, the Minister can set aside only a decision of a review authority and, except for certain illegals who apply within the concessionary period, illegals have no right of review. Therefore, they cannot benefit from the limited ministerial discretion available.

It is essential to provide a mechanism to allow our system to take account of exceptional circumstances. Unless this is done, our legal system will be brought into disrepute and people who deserve compassionate consideration will be driven underground. We are already facing the unfortunate situation of people applying to the courts for decisions where the department has made too strict an interpretation. This will continue until the Government puts in place regulations to clarify the situation.

Another complexity in the regulations is the positive candour requirement. This means that the applicant must disclose any material change of circumstances. However, despite the fact that the categories of application have been strictly defined, what constitutes a material change of circumstances is not so defined. If applicants neglect to disclose such information, whatever that is, they may be illegal immigrants. Therefore, it is important that the material particulars be defined to avoid problems with innocent illegals in the future and to have some certainty in the legislation covering them.

After 31 October, exceptions to the laws governing illegals should and will be at an absolute minimum. However, action must be taken before 31 October and we must find means to reduce the current undesirable level of illegals. If the Committee's recommendations are accepted, this will be achieved by the carrot and stick approach. Illegal entrants leaving Australia voluntarily before 31 October will be able to reapply from abroad without any time restrictions, that is, as soon as they reach their destination. However, illegal entrants apprehended after 31 October will suffer time restrictions on their ability to apply for re-entry to Australia. They will also have to meet costs associated with being deported and, on recent information, several thousand have chosen to leave to avoid these disadvantages.

As part of this strategy, it is also necessary to enable people in exceptional circumstances to at least have their cases heard. To this end, the Committee recommends, and the Australian Democrats support, empowering the Immigration Review Tribunal to consider applications firstly, from people who believe they are innocent illegals and, secondly, from people who have been here more than five years. However, these are threshold requirements. Applicants will also have to satisfy public interest criteria and will be required to demonstrate that they have made a positive and substantial contribution to Australia. To misrepresent these threshold requirements as a five-year absorption amnesty is wrong. It should be noted that this five-year requirement is not a qualification, but merely a precondition to have an application considered. This approach acknowledges the need for tight controls but tempers the approach with compassion for people who deserve consideration on public policy and humanitarian grounds.

Before I conclude, I need to pay tribute to the secretariat staff, who have done tremendous work in a very tight time scale. Robina Mills, Heidi Quinlan and Francis Kleiss deserve the highest commendation, as does the legal consultant, Dr Kathryn Cronin. The Government should recognise that if it is to impose tight time lines, as it has on this occasion, the Committee must have adequate resources to avoid putting undue pressure on its staff, and indeed on the people that appear before it and the members of the Committee.

The Committee has amended the views of the previous Committee that the Act be amended to allow for such appeals, and I hope to see the necessary amendments presented to the Parliament at the earliest opportunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly about this report on debt recovery under the Social Security Act and the Veterans' Entitlements Act. I would like to begin by congratulating the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on a comprehensive survey of what is a vexed and complex area. While I welcome the general thrust of these recommendations, I would like to highlight just a couple of concerns.

SPEECH.PARA: Before doing that, however, I would like to point out that this reference to a standing committee may not have been necessary-in fact, would not have been necessary-if the new debt recovery provisions had not been included in the legislation. Honourable senators may recall that, at the time, the Australian Democrats opposed these provisions because the community groups were telling us the provisions involved elements of unfairness and victimisation, and made a number of false assumptions, particularly about sole parents. I think this report vindicates both the concerns of these community groups and the actions that the Democrats took at that time.

It is important that this report is clearly placed in the right context. When discussing the recovery of overpayments to pensioners and beneficiaries we are not talking about massive amounts of fraud as some people persist in doing. As the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) noted at the time of the Budget, the cost to the Department of Social Security of overpayments last year-and that includes all the deliberate fraud-amounted to less than 0.1 of one per cent of total payments made to pensioners and beneficiaries. Indeed, in any one year, as most overpayments are due to error, there are fewer than 2,500 prosecutions across Australia for fraud. We need to be clear, as we interpret this report, that there is no widespread rorting of the social security system.

This report identifies numerous problems with the way the Department of Social Security recovers debts from its clients, and I believe we need to take up these matters if we are to make sure that the Department provides humane and supportive services, thereby ensuring that the vast majority of honest pensioners and beneficiaries are not subjected to undue and unfair practices.

It is particularly pleasing that this report-and this is recommendation 21-recommends that payments made under the Social Security Act in respect of children are not to be used to recover any overpayments. As the Committee notes, it is simply not on to have children suffer as a consequence of their parents' obligation to repay money. I trust the Department will take heed of this recommendation. I note, with great concern, that the Department's draft debt recovery manual contains provisions that are in direct conflict with this recommendation.

It is also pleasing to see recommendations in relation to the Department's obligations to supply accurate, understandable information to all its clients. Many pensioners and beneficiaries complain about the maze of information they have to negotiate their way through and the lack of specific information that they require from the Department.

The Department has been criticised for its information practices for some time, most notably by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs in its report last year on the quality of services provided by the Department. This report re-emphasises the pressing need for some action to be taken on this.

In particular, the report recommends that there is a need to address the issue of forms and standard letters, recommendation 11; written notification of alleged overpayments, recommendation 12; clear and precise calculations of alleged overpayments, recommendation 10; and basic information about the availability of appeal rights, also recommendation 10.

I would also like to commend the Committee for its recommendation that welfare rights units and community legal centres be funded to provide competent and independent advice for social security clients, recommendation 29. These types of services are most important as pensioners and beneficiaries do not have access to expensive lawyers and they are up against a complex and frequently inflexible system.

Another positive recommendation, and one that recognises the small amount of deliberate fraud within the system, is No. 15 which addresses the issue of clients being paid one particular type of pension or benefit when, in fact, they were entitled to another benefit. The Committee has rightly recommended that the Department should offset overpayments against the payment to which the client was, in fact, entitled.

Finally, I make the comment that this report is a very positive move in the right direction. The general thrust is enlightened. Hopefully, the Government will not leave this report on a shelf gathering dust, but we will see it implemented and, hopefully, that will not be in the too distant future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

APPENDIX 2
RESPONSE BY DR P. INGRAM CROMACK
AGREED TO BY DR CROMACK
AND THE COMMITTEE OF PRIVILEGES
PURSUANT TO RESOLUTION 5(7)(b) OF THE SENATE OF
25 FEBRUARY 1988

I wish to make a rebuttal statement in relation to the unfair and damaging remarks made by former Senator Jenkins in the Senate in which she personally named me (Hansard 28th May, 1990). My reputation has been adversely affected, I have suffered professional injury, financial loss and stress (and my family as well) as a result of these allegations. These allegations have been described by Mr. Gavan Troy, Productivity &Labour Relations Minister, W.A. Parliament, in the West Australian of Saturday, June 2nd, 1990 as being unsubstantiated. These were again repeated by former Senator Jenkins in The Australian Doctor Weekly of 15.6.90.

Like a few of my Senior Orthopaedic colleagues in this State, I do see (for the purposes of a medico-legal opinion) difficult compensation claims. I am asked to give an opinion based on the history, clinical examination and investigations in claims which have dragged on sometimes for two or three years at least, and where the patient has seen six, seven or eight different doctors, all with differing shades of opinion. These are very difficult and time-consuming cases and require the expertise of long years of experience in the speciality. Hence, the demand usually falls upon the shoulders of the few more senior members for these types of complex cases. It is not that any organisation is choosing``pet Doctors''.

One has several duties to perform-the chief being to give a privileged medico-legal report without fear or favour whether it be in the patient's interest or in an insurance organisation's interest. These opinions have always been regarded as sacrosanct and not to be distributed to third parties. Unfortunately, this has occurred and medico-legal privilege has been broken and abused.

It is important also that public monies be protected from false claims in these difficult economic times when there have been cut-backs in Public Hospital funding thereby reducing their working capacity and producing long waiting lists of patients for hip arthroplasties, etc.
Doctors do not ``cease patients' compensation payments''. It is a decision of the Court based on evidence.

Most of these claims are referred by Solicitors and Insurance Companies and only a few are purely private patients. This is because of the Medicare and Hospital Benefit restrictions where the patient can obtain no refund whatsoever for an Insurance examination. In this State, there are only a handful of Doctors willing to see these difficult claims because of their complex nature, the problems associated with being called to Court and if the referrals are not under the auspices of the Legal profession or an Insurance organisation, then there is a considerable risk that the fees will never be paid at all or if they are paid, the waiting time is often three or four years.
Complaints have been made and two such serve as good examples:-

(a) I was accused of being responsible for a patient's workers' compensation payments ceasing. However, in actual fact, the evidence is quite to the contrary because the patient's solicitor omitted to lodge the required claim within the time specified by the Court.

(b) Another complaint was that I did not accept the patient's alleged degree of severe disability and this is correct, as I did not feel that this patient (who had a minor, simple, tennis elbow) did have very much disability. I agreed with the patient's own treating Orthopaedic Surgeon who stated that the patient had only l0% disability in the affected arm i.e. the tennis elbow.
These are two documented complaints where the proof shows me to be entirely innocent of these unsubstantiated allegations.

As a result of former Senator Jenkins' statements (repeated on the A.B.C.) the front and name plate of my consulting rooms were filmed by Channel 2 and were clearly identified and shown on the 6.00 p.m. News on 3.6.90. My consent was not obtained and I consider this an invasion of privacy.

On the subject of R.S.I., cervico-brachial neuritis or whatever other name one likes to give this alleged condition, over a period of 17 months in 1,100 patients, I have only seen eleven cases of alleged R.S.I.-this is only 1% of the total.

I see compensation cases for Australia Post however, since it is well known (like the majority of my colleagues) that I do not believe R.S.I. to be a discrete clinical entity, to obviate any dispute it has been thought wise for me not to see any R.S.I. cases for Australia Post. This evidence is also documented.

Regarding the alleged condition of R.S.I., it is not a clinical condition accepted by Australian Orthopaedic Surgeons or the Society of Hand Surgeons as being a condition in its own right. Pain in the arm is a common complaint, and we believe in this day and age, that with sophisticated investigation, coupled with careful clinical observation, a diagnosis can always be made of a definitive type such as ``disc disease'' in the neck or a pinched nerve at the elbow, for instance. I am supported in this contention by other Specialists in other fields.

The umbrella term ``R.S.I.'' is used to explain symptoms without signs and is thought to co-exist with diagnosed organic disorders (Browne 1984) and to be the explanation for symptoms in excess of those to be expected with diagnosed physical disorders and for symptoms continuing for longer than expected, with diagnosed physical disorders. Used in these ways, the concept of R.S.I. is in all ways, consistent with what is known as functional overlay in legal circles and conversion symptoms amongst psychiatrists.
(See Lucinda Lucire's Submission to the R.S.I. Task Force Committee 1984/85.)
I therefore, like my Orthopaedic colleagues and many other colleagues, am not alone in my beliefs of the pathology of this alleged condition.

I trust the above is an adequate explanation and does explain the damage done to my professional reputation and integrity and the suffering it has caused, both stress and financial. As has been said, former Senator Jenkins has been using unsubstantiated information.
I would ask the Privileges Committee in its wisdom, to table this rebuttal in the Senate so that it may be incorporated in Hansard as a permanent record.
