As I indicated, we oppose the creation of the Authority for various reasons. I also mentioned that when this Bill was introduced in the other House the aim was to transfer the statutory authority when created to Newcastle. The Opposition spokesman in the other place, the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), made a point of saying that this was blatant pork-barrelling by the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) and his colleagues in the Newcastle area. The responses from the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) and the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) were shock, horror-this Government would never engage in pork-barrelling! I quoted a few statements from them. For example, Mr Bob Brown stated:

SPEECH.PARA: It is just coincidental that my electorate adjoins Newcastle.
I emphasise that the decision to locate AMSA in Newcastle was based on objective reasons.
I also pointed out that a degree of sensibility was introduced into this debate by none other than Senator Walsh who sprung the Government when, among other things, he said:
Circuses are taking over from the real issues and such a move has no functional purpose.

I point out that the people responsible for the safety program who would be represented by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) are already located in Canberra. To propose a move of these people at a cost to the taxpayer estimated in the second reading speech at around $10m, but subsequently amended to around $17m, is a gross waste. No wonder Senator Walsh made the remark that `circuses are taking over from the real issues'.

If the Authority were already in Newcastle, it would be equally as ludicrous to suggest that it be moved back to Canberra; but it is already here. In this modern day and age with transport and communications the way they are, there would be no justifiable reason for that move. Since the Bill was introduced into the House of Representatives the Government has now changed its mind. We now find that, recognising the proposed and very stupid waste of taxpayers' money involved in this very cynical exercise, the Minister, Senator Bob Collins, has decided that the Australian Maritime Safety Authority will stay where it is. Mr Deputy President, if you will excuse the observation, it looks like a Bob going each way-Senator Bob Collins going in one direction and Mr Bob Brown, the other Minister, going in the other.

After all these protests and indignation about the very suggestion that the location was politically inspired pump- priming, what has been the response of Minister Brown now that Minister Collins has decided to keep the Authority in Canberra? In the Sydney Morning Herald of 15 September, Minister Brown is quoted as describing the back flip as `outrageous'. The report then goes on to state:

Apparently as a sop to Newcastle and the three Labor MP's who represent the Newcastle region the Government is now looking for other ways it can invest in Newcastle much of the $10.9 million allocated for the project.
So much for the protestations in the other place by Mr Brown, Mr Morris and others who were so shocked at the suggestion that this was pork-barrelling at the expense of Australian taxpayers.

Again, to quote the remarks of Senator Walsh, `it was nothing more or less than a circus'. What a blatant abuse of taxpayers' money to buy votes! He also said that this was a major plank in the Government's platform of micro-economic reform. What the public and the people of Newcastle need is genuine micro-economic reform. They want lower interest rates, as does the rest of Australia; they want lower inflation, as does the rest of Australia; and they want less tax-all of which will make a positive contribution to their future well-being and their long term job prospects.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some remarks in relation to the Maritime Safety Authority Bill 1990. It is a matter that has been of considerable interest in my electorate since the idea first came up. I certainly join my colleagues in opposing the legislation, which proposes to create a new statutory authority-the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA).

SPEECH.PARA: My interest in this proposal for the creation of the Authority dates back to the end of last year when the creation of the body was announced by the Government. It was not announced against a background of calls from the maritime industries for any form of restructuring of sea safety services or any call for relocation of sea safety services that we might have expected would have preceded an announcement of this kind. Yet it was announced and from the outset it was clear that in addition to the creation of the new body, the Authority I have referred to, it was the intention of the Government to establish it at a location outside Canberra from where the sea safety organisation had operated for many years, and it was to be placed in Newcastle.

The whole process begs the question as to why the Government was so determined to make these changes and why they should take place in Newcastle. It is my understanding that the industry this organisation is supposed to serve not only was not seeking these changes, but also was not even consulted about them. Since the proposal came to light late last year, concern has been expressed within the maritime industries about the likely increases in costs and charges that will arise out of the costly exercise of creating this new Authority and relocating staff from Canberra to Newcastle.

In recent days the Government has recognised the considerable financial arguments against relocation outside Canberra and has announced that the Authority, if its establishment goes ahead, will remain in Canberra. That is a decision which I welcome. In my view there should never have been any question of moving the personnel involved with the sea safety organisation, whether under the present arrangements or as part of a new authority, outside the Australian Capital Territory.

My remarks should not in any way be construed as an attack on Newcastle. My view about the location of sea safety personnel would have been the same if the proposed location had been Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, or any other site. There is no reason why it should be shifted from Canberra. The arguments against a move from the ACT to any other city would be equally valid.

The moving of personnel would have been an unjustified waste of taxpayers' money and would have served no useful purpose in sea safety. There would have been the cost of physically moving the equipment and personnel to a new location; the cost of accommodation at a new site; the cost of moving those staff who remained in the service to the new place; and the cost of redundancy packages for the families of staff unwilling to disrupt their families and who wanted to stay in Canberra. Of those there were many. And of course there would have been the loss of expertise of those who would be leaving the Sea Safety Centre if it moved, causing considerable dislocation to families who otherwise would have stayed in Canberra.

In recent times it was discovered that the property in Newcastle which was to be the home under the proposal-NESCA House-was considerably contaminated with asbestos. I do not believe it has ever been ascertained what additional cost that has incurred or what additional cost might have been incurred by shifting from the proposed venue to a new venue. Those are only the monetary costs. The cost to the employees in terms of the disruption of their family life would have been considerable. Also, as I mentioned, the skills and expertise that would have been lost indicates to me that the move should not be made.

What seemed surprising to me was the fact that the Government showed little interest in the more than 200 employees and their families who would have been affected by the move. I had letters from many who were upset about it. They indicated that they would not move because the impact on their children would be too great. Certainly the union to which they belong was opposed to the sea safety unit being moved from Canberra. Perhaps the Government was misled by the Department's very optimistic submission to Cabinet which estimated that 80 per cent of employees would be happy to move from Canberra with the AMSA. From the information that I have obtained, I do not believe that that was an accurate assessment of the number that wanted to move. I think the figure was arrived at without looking at the new structure. Very few people were happy to move and I believe that it would have resulted, at least for a period, in a downgrading in the service which could have been provided while new people were recruited and trained in the necessary work of the area. Ship survey services and other operations would also have been affected had the unit moved from Canberra to Newcastle.

The Centre has responsibility for search in an area covering 11 per cent of the earth's surface. It operates for 24 hours a day and is well equipped with very sophisticated computer and satellite equipment, as well as highly skilled staff. My real concern of course was with the impact on the staff. An enforced move would have damaged the search and rescue unit's ability to carry out its functions as efficiently as it has in recent times. Recently it moved within Canberra from Weston to Belconnen. It cost a considerable amount to relocate the unit and that did not include the cost of people moving houses, as would have been the case had the unit gone to Newcastle.

The grievances and the views of the employees-as I mentioned, there were 200 or so-seemed to carry little weight with the Minister who previously held the portfolio, that is, before Senator Collins became the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. He was determined, it seemed, to see that the project proceed both with the formation of the Authority and the transfer to Newcastle. The only conclusion which could be drawn from the former Minister's determination was that he felt there was some other benefit for the move to Newcastle. I think that his comments in the last few days raise the question: Why did he want it in Newcastle? Many people have been surprised at the way he has reacted to the decision, which is obviously a Cabinet decision made in the light of a submission that the present Minister had put to it.

Two issues are involved here. One is the establishment of the Authority itself and the other is the move. I have spoken principally to the reason why it should not have moved and welcome the fact that the Minister has now indicated that it will not move. I was particularly concerned because this would have been one of a series of moves which have occurred in recent years of moving public servants from Canberra, the national capital. The former Human Rights Commission, which was established in Canberra, was moved to Sydney and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal was moved from Canberra to Brisbane. Mr Deputy President, you may have been pleased to see that happen, but in my view it flies in the face of the reason for the existence of a national capital. Canberra did not get the aviation college that everybody said should be based here. Instead it was located in Tasmania. People would not be surprised to learn that we feel there is a pattern of taking things away from Canberra when it suits-taking away organisations which ought to be properly placed in the national capital. I am pleased that in this instance the very strong case against moving the staff from Canberra has prevailed.

All that remains to be resolved now is whether or not it is necessary to establish the Authority and whether it will be of any benefit. In the absence of any demonstrated benefit either to the Sea Safety Centre, the staff of the service, the clients of the service or the taxpayers of Australia, I would assert that the Authority should not go ahead. It is my view that the Government should cut its losses at this stage and abandon the legislation. It has shown that it was willing to reconsider the merits of the relocation and I congratulate it on being prepared to put reason and logic above political considerations. I urge a similar re-examination of the proposal to set up the Authority. I do not believe that it is necessary and I suggest that this legislation be withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I would like to make it clear that it was my understanding that I was fifth on the speakers list and that is why I was absent from the chamber earlier.

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, the Democrats recognise the value of greater input to the operation of maritime safety from the industry itself. The Board of this Authority is to be comprised of representatives from a broad spectrum of government, union, business and industry groups. The Democrats see this as an essential element in ensuring that the new Authority's operations are as responsive to the needs of these groups as possible, and we welcome the opportunity that the establishment of the Authority provides for this increased consultation to occur.

With respect to the proposed move to Newcastle, which seems to have occupied a very large proportion of this debate, the Democrats have a firm commitment to decentralisation and have proposed or supported a wide range of local and regional employment initiatives. But, clearly, the costs of relocation to Newcastle were increasing dramatically, and combined with the lack of appropriate office space in the area and the discovery of considerable levels of asbestos in the one suitable building, this meant that establishing the Authority in the Newcastle area was inappropriate. The cost of the move had got to the stage where it simply could not be justified as anything more than an abuse of taxpayers' money. In contrast, the cost of establishing the restructured Authority here in Canberra will be around $2.5m, and the Democrats believe that the benefits of the Authority warrant this cost.

In supporting this Bill, the Democrats reject the Opposition's view that only the private sector has the capacity and the right to run efficient commercial enterprises. It is this type of thinking that will lead to the Opposition selling off completely Telecom, OTC Ltd, Australian Airlines and Qantas even when, for example, Australian Airlines is easily out-performing its privately owned competitor. Similarly, the Democrats support the establishment of a commercially oriented and highly responsible authority to replace the maritime operations division of the Department of Transport and Communications. We believe that it is appropriate that the Authority be largely funded by levies on commercial shipping, navigational aids and oil pollution prevention and recovery. At the same time, however, we believe that it is vital that the funding of search and rescue operations in this area be absolutely guaranteed. The Democrats do have a couple of concerns about the legislation. Our first concern was highlighted in the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills report No. 5. This concern relates to the delegation of power as outlined in clause 58 of the Bill. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contribution to the debate, and I will not detain the Senate for very long.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition is opposing this legislation on philosophical grounds and it is certainly entitled to do that. I note, however, the comments of their spokesperson about the Newcastle option, which has occupied much of the debate in recent times rather than the purpose of the organisation itself. TALK.START.PARA: —What did Bob Brown say afterwards?

—I intend to refer to that. But that simply is not correct. In fact, this organisation originally existed in the Port of Melbourne, until it was moved to Canberra by the previous conservative Government. I am not suggesting that was an incorrect decision at the time. It has operated here in Canberra for the eight years since then. SPEECH.PARA: I stress `headquarters' because what seems to have been totally overlooked in the recent debate is that this is a regionalised service that does have significant port-based operations. It is the head office we are talking about that is here in Canberra and not its entire operation. I have read comments made recently in the New South Wales Parliament in a debate recently supported by the colleagues of Senator Parer. They paid no attention at all to what their colleagues here are saying about it in supporting a motion put forward by the Opposition that the impression has been created that this organisation was entirely Canberra-based, hundreds of miles away from a maritime setting. The Authority is currently located in six regional ports, but when its operations are streamlined they will be cut down to three port-based regional operations and its head office here in Canberra.

The decision was taken to base that on sensible grounds. There was a long term benefit attached to that as well, in that it certainly would have improved the long term opportunities for the organisations to enhance its recruitment capacity for specialist marine people knowing that it was based in a port. I was very honest, open and frank about that in the Estimates committees where it was raised previously and in other debates. So that was the operational basis. It was costed at that time at $7m. The cost of establishing it in Canberra was estimated as between $1m and $2m at that time.

On becoming Minister, I was anxious to expedite this decision. I discovered that costs had risen, for entirely valid reasons. I want to make two quick points about that. There has been a lot of discussion of this matter in recent days. There is understandable angst on the part of Novocastrians. Indeed, I share my roots with Senator Kernot in that I am also a Novocastrian. I was born in Newcastle and educated at Newcastle Boys High. I took no particular pleasure out of being faced with what I was faced with when I became Minister. What had happened, for reasons that were largely out of the control of the Government in terms of the delays that were caused-the Federal election, the earthquake in Newcastle, limitations on accommodation options available in Newcastle, and the subsequent discovery of asbestos in NESCA House, which was the only available option in Newcastle-was that, whichever way one looked at it, all the options constituted a particularly inedible form of sandwich.

However, it was necessary to make a decision. Costs had risen from $7m to $11m. They subsequently rose again from $11m to $16m. I want to make two points in relation to those rises, and I have no doubt that anyone who is interested enough to pursue this matter will be able to pursue it during Estimates committee hearings, which is the appropriate place to discuss that sort of complexity, rather than taking the time of this chamber. I will save it until then if anyone is interested to pursue it.

An impression has also been created about the employees of AMSA who were affected and who did not want to move. One could hardly blame them, but again that is no reflection on Newcastle. I share Senator Reid's view on that. It is simply that the employees who have lived and worked in a community for eight years, who enjoy living in their own houses and having their kids go to schools in that area, did not like the prospect of having to move. That is perfectly natural. I am sure they did not like it when they were moved from Melbourne eight years ago.

The figures that were put together by those who were affected by this decision were largely put together by the range of Commonwealth government departments that normally operate in the area of moving public servants. There were the Transport and Storage Group, the Department of Administrative Services, the industrial relations people, and senior executives of the Department of Transport and Communications who were not directly affected by the move. Despite the fact that my office carried out its own independent examination of these figures, I asked the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) to carry out his own independent examination of the figures, which he did. The only difference between the Transport and Communications estimates and the Department of Finance estimates of the cost of the move to Newcastle was that the estimate of the Department of Finance was slightly higher than that of the Department of Transport and Communications.

A second matter then intruded which was important. I refer to the staff loss from the headquarters here in Canberra. This has not intruded to a significant extent in the viability of the operations of this organisation. However, it was clear that, if those operations kept going, and whichever option was adopted in terms of accommodation in Newcastle by early next year, it would be difficult for this organisation to sustain a viable operation.

I say, with no disrespect to my colleagues, that at the end of the day the person who has to stand in this place and bear the responsibility for loss of life at sea is me. It is not the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris), the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) or the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Bob Brown). It is I. I could hardly in good conscience responsibly proceed with a decision when my own judgment, entirely unrelated to the cost of this exercise, indicated that that organisation would face significant difficulties with either the Nestor House option or the only other available option-a brand new building which currently does not exist in Newcastle-if there were a further year's delay. I was not prepared to place the organisation, which is entirely related to the subject of the preservation of life at sea and safety, in that position.

It was on that basis that I took the decision back to Cabinet. All the arguments were canvassed in Cabinet, and it is important to understand that. The contrary figures that were prepared on the cost of the move were presented to Cabinet. The estimates of the Department of Finance were presented, as were those of my Department, and the point as to operational efficiency was also put. Cabinet, with all that material before it, took the difficult decision-and it was a difficult decision-in view of all the circumstances to reverse its original decision and to retain the organisation here in Canberra.

I conclude by saying that after 1 January next year the decisions as to the future location of the operations of this organisation will rest not with the Government, but with the Board of AMSA. That is important and is worthy of note. With the exception of search and rescue, this organisation will extract the majority of its income from charges that it levies against the industry for services such as marine survey that it provides. Therefore, any decision subsequently made by the Board of AMSA after 1 January when it commences operations will have to be justified to the industry from which the Board derives its income. I think that that is an appropriate way to proceed. I thank honourable senators for their contribution to the debate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the Dried Fruits Levy Amendment Bill 1990. Dried fruits are not big in my electorate-in fact, if I am pinned down, I would have to say that I do not have any. But what I do have is a very large number-and I would be a prime example-of what are far more important, namely, constant and dedicated consumers. Any industry that is concentrated on production ahead of consumption inevitably must have major difficulties. Over the years there have been problems in this area from time to time. Besides that, I like the people involved in this industry and I have spoken in this chamber a number of times on this industry-indeed, at least a dozen times since I came to this place. It is a great Australian industry. It produces an excellent product. It is a most important adjunct to the other industries of the area. On a world basis the growers are highly productive and they are working to become even better. On a quality basis, the Australian producers are second to none.

SPEECH.PARA: However, it is not all straight sailing. Even though one would expect that an industry that is doing everything right would have no problems, that is not the case. For instance, the European Community (EC) is opening up to new entrants and has allowed in Greece, which produces substantial quantities of dried fruits and which as part of the deal is heavily subsidised, and I mean heavily. Mr Lloyd in another place mentioned $70m a year. Let me quote what he said on page 1343 of the House of Representatives Hansard of 22 August:

The campaign against Turkey has been easier, I understand, than the problem with Greece. Greece is a part of the European Community and is receiving huge export subsidies. According to the Chairman of the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation, it is costing the European Community $70m a year to protect the Greek product. In Greece the grower sells to the packer for $2,100 a tonne. Then the packer sells to the buyer for $1,700 a tonne and the EC pays assistance to the packer of $1,300 a tonne, as well as $25 a month storage charge. So after all that subsidy, Greece last year had to feed 25,000 tonnes of its 78,000 tonnes of production to livestock.
That is what we are up against.

Then there is the United States of America which also has large production subsidies. That is what happens overseas. At home we have to contend with the fancy value of the Australian dollar, the interest rates regime, the costs of the Australian waterfront, and so on and so forth. Then there are Australia's normal social costs which countries like Greece and Turkey do not have to meet. The Australian majority-that is the noisy majority-who do not have to compete with overseas industry have no reason to be concerned as to whether there is an Australian dried fruits industry-or any other industry if it comes to that. But every time that some other extra cost is added in Australia, someone else in the competitive, productive sector loses more of his livelihood. In this case it is the dried fruit growers.

We should all be proud of the people involved in the dried fruits industry. They are leaders in the world, although only small in world tonnages. Our industry has made good inroads into New Zealand, Germany, Canada and, more recently, Asia and in every case has done so on the basis of quality. For example, one has only to look at a pack of, say, `Angas Park' apricots against those awful little``el cheapos'' of the supermarket chains in their own packages to see what I mean.

Recently my colleague Senator Calvert carried out a survey on imported foodstuffs, and dried fruits was an example. Why, for goodness sake, should we want to buy commodities such as strawberry jam from Egypt, dried fruits from Greece and Turkey or potatoes from Japan? I just wonder about these things.

We know the standards of production here. We know the care and attention in processing. I never feel as sure about products such as the ones I have mentioned that are imported from countries whose approach to presentation and operation is much different from ours. I ask the Minister to pass on to Cabinet the general and increasing concerns of the community about the importation of foodstuffs from countries where there may be less than an equivalent standard of production, presentation, packaging or labelling.

Perhaps we can start by making a bigger effort on labelling. Initially we can require the country of origin to be much more prominent than it currently is. I make a regular practice of looking for this in supermarkets. Particularly of late I have been looking around the dried fruits section. If, on the first inspection of a dried fruit pack, someone can find the country of origin he has had a very good look or he has just got new glasses. In the meantime, we need to examine this matter more thoroughly.

I have no objection to people being able to buy overseas products, but I do want them to be fully aware that the choice they make is for the imported product. I want them to understand fully from which country they are buying. Contents need to be more fully described and packaging must conform to what we have determined Australian manufacturers must provide on the basis of what Australian consumers are entitled to. We must make adequate provision to attend to cases of alleged dumping. What we have now certainly is not adequate.

This Bill provides for quite substantial increases in growers' levies to go to research. It has the support of the growers. I congratulate them for doing this. Of the levy, currently approximately one-third goes to improving fruit quality, about one-third to improving the efficiency of dried vine fruit products, about one-sixth to developing new products and the balance to various sundries. With our small quantities, there can be no doubt that quality is the way to go.

We produce 57,000 tonnes of sultanas of a total world production of 720,000 tonnes. As honourable senators can see, we produce a pretty small proportion. I also note that we produce 3,000 tonnes of dried apricots. We are second in the world in this area. Turkey, which is ahead of us, produces 35,000 tonnes a year.

Australians have left their mark on the dried fruit industry. Through research in drying and growing, irrigation and trellising, breeding and handling, all of which have been important to this industry, from the mid-1950s to the mid-1980s production more than doubled from a little over two tonnes to almost 4 1/2 tonnes to the hectare. That is a very good increase.

I commend the industry for its path along the road to higher quality and increased productivity. I trust that its extra contribution will be spent wisely. It is a very good little industry. In fact, it is a great little industry. It certainly has the support of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Dried Fruits Levy Amendment Bill 1990 I am pleased to endorse the levy. I agreed with a lot of what Senator Archer said. SPEECH.PARA: As I understand it, the result of this proposed measure will be that more funds will be available for research both from within the industry and, as a result of the Government's dollar for dollar support, from outside the industry. As was noted in the debate on this matter in the other place, one of the reasons that this industry retains its superior productivity and quality is that the industry itself has dedicated funds to research. It is that sort of research which has presented us with an industry which, as Senator Archer described, is a very good industry for Australia. The industry contributes to our domestic market in terms of quality. It also contributes quite a considerable amount of money in terms of the export market. It is a strong industry which, over many years, has been beneficial to Australia.

I am concerned that this industry is subjected to conflicting government policies. I believe they are conflicting because they have brought about some frustrating contradictions. The Government and the primary industry itself have funded research and other programs which have brought us wonderful varieties. They have brought us clean, uncontaminated and pesticide-free products which are virusfree, packaged as Senator Archer wants, date stamped, hygienically tested, and examined and produced using labour paid at award rates.

Through the programs and research in this country we have something to be proud of. That is all to no avail if we allow entry into our market of producers who have not had these very constraints and, to some extent, these advantages.

In debates about trade policy, tariffs, et cetera, we hear a great deal about level playing fields or some other such cliche which sounds attractive. But when it is translated we hear about removing market barriers; we hear about allowing true market forces to determine trading levels. That is not the real world at all; it is just as much a fiction as the idea of level playing fields. It is all nonsense. While ever we have such a multitude of factors affecting the selling price of our farm produce, while our producers carry the constraints I referred to earlier, overseas competitors are being cosseted into our markets.

We have a provision which differentiates between developing and developed countries for the entry of imported dried fruits, for example. Such a provision is ridiculous if it is exploited by callous multinationals which locate in developing countries to qualify for Australia's lower tariff rates and owe little or no allegiance to their country of convenience. They have used it in the same way that for some decades now shipping agents have used a port of convenience as their registration point. These operators owe little allegiance to their country of convenience. They then rip their profits off back to owners in the developed world.

Notwithstanding this situation, which is more prevalent than we might imagine, we have other problems with the definition of developing countries. According to our present definition, Turkey qualifies as a developing nation and takes advantage of the lowest tariff rates we offer for dried apricots. Surely we all know that Turkey has been developing its dried apricot industry for hundreds, if not thousands, of years, and it still has not got it right. Its product, as Senator Archer said, is still inferior, contaminated and of dubious nutritional value. That is apart from the production area's proximity to Chernobyl and the hazards which might be associated with that area.

Thankfully, our dried fruit industry has shown a great capacity to market its product based on quality. The marketing arm of the industry has been able to stave off the threat that the Turkish product has mounted, based mainly on price and assisted with our generous provisions.

Our dried fruit producers are still saddled with having to compete within the jungle out there, and it bears no resemblance to a level playing field. It might be level at our end but up the other end, where the other producers are operating, there are hurdles, ramps, supports and sandpits of all descriptions. Occasionally we even have boulders dropped in our end. Our producers, our team, have to pick them up before we even start playing the game.

I do endorse sincerely a great deal of what Senator Archer said, especially with regard to packaging and alleged dumping. As he is, I am concerned about the sort of competition we must battle against. In no way do I want to imply that the provisions of this Bill will make things harder. In fact, I think the very fact that the producers have supported the change to the levy as contained in the Bill emphasises their knowledge that it is only through research and the refinement of the quality of their product that they will be able to rise above all the difficulties that I have mentioned to the extent where we will continue to have a viable and very successful industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to make some observations on the National Museum of Australia. At the outset, I would like to join those in this chamber who have supported in principle the concept of a museum that serves all Australians and visitors to this great nation as a focal point and unifying symbol of the great achievements of this country; a museum that brings together the diverse elements of our common past, both prior to settlement and since; and, above all, a museum that will serve to encapsulate the achievements of our country, by all its peoples, towards common prosperity, freedom and the quality of life that so many sections of our community so often take for granted-a museum that honours the achievements of great Australians.
—And to ensure the preservation of our old Parliament House.

—That is quite right. It is with some concern that I have observed recent community debate on the treatment of the themes chosen for the National Museum of Australia. I draw the Senate's attention to a recent article in the latest edition of the excellent monthly Quadrant.

SPEECH.PARA: The three main themes of the museum as stated in the annual report for 1988-89 are Aboriginal Australia, history of settlement post-1788, and the interaction of the Australian people with the environment. In the treatment of these themes the museum must not only present a balanced overview of the cultural diversity of this nation but extend its brief to the heritage, institutions, common aims and beliefs and untiring commitment to the betterment of all its people that have united this country. The agenda of the museum speaks of the cultural diversity of this nation, but I have to say that to focus on diversity while avoiding the major sources of unity in our society is to betray the very nature of some of this country's greatest achievements.

The path to the development of the National Museum has not been an easy one. In recognising the uncertain climate surrounding the museum, created by the less than consistent support of the current Government, which has posed some problems in the planning of the museum, I would like to canvass some of the elements that I see as being essential to the creation of a truly representative and unifying national museum.

I have obtained some of the promotional brochures of the museum and on reading these brochures I am concerned not so much at what is said in the material-although I have some qualifications there-but at what the material is silent about. For example, the material is silent about some of the most fundamental institutions, cannons and traditions of our society.

No mention is made of the Constitution, the monarchy, the judiciary, the rule of law or our armed forces, and only cursory attention is given to the political history component of the museum. Yet these institutions have served us as a unifying force and underlying strength, holding the diverse elements of this nation together through depression, drought, war and all of the hard times to create a society that many in the rest of the world look upon with some envy.

The museum's publications at times take an overtly negative stance towards this nation's English heritage. A negative reference to the British tradition is made in one of the pamphlets. As a person with Scottish blood and Scottish heritage, I presume that by British it means English. It represents an example of the alienation that we see so often in this type of material of the majority of Australians, who recognise the enormous debt this nation owes to the first settlers and the structures they gave this nation as a foundation for our future development-a foundation that has allowed the nation to prosper as one of the world's first democracies.

Where is the emphasis in this material on the tremendous development of our economy in the last century or so, which in just 200 years has provided a level of material well-being, security and comfort to which many other nations of the world can only aspire? We have achieved this position by developing a harsh and formidable environment through our wheat, wool, mining, beef and manufacturing industries, but, above all, through the back-breaking and tireless efforts of the Australian people.

I could find in the material that I was able to obtain no mention of our system of free enterprise, freedom of endeavour and entrepreneurship which has provided the impetus for the triumph that is the development of Australia. Where are the references to Australian literature? Where are the references to our film industry, our wealth of musical talent and our significant and substantial schools of painting? These rate barely a mention.

To take stock of all the elements which have interrelated to create the nation we have today and would like to see in the future would be a task beyond the time limits which I have this evening. Yet in the creation of a truly national, unifying museum that will stand as a proud symbol of this nation, such fundamental elements as I have touched upon this evening must be given some emphasis. Above all, we must be cautious to avoid the highly selective and consequently divisive atmosphere that characterised the early planning of our bicentennial celebrations in 1988. We cannot allow the national symbol that will be the National Museum of Australia to be compromised by sectional interests or unbalanced views.

I would like Senator Richardson, the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment Tourism and Territories, to look at the issues I have raised here this evening and to ensure that the National Museum will represent all Australians, not just a narrow, ideological agenda.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

(1) The bulk of waste material produced in Parliament House is processed through the central waste system (CWS). The waste material consists mainly of the contents of office waste bins and large amounts of newspapers, reports and other waste paper. The waste is collected by contract cleaning staff and fed into the CWS chutes which are positioned at strategic locations on each floor of the building. Non-recyclable waste (eg. Kitchen waste and building materials) is fed into the garbage compactor at the loading dock and subsequently taken to the tip. The answer to question 2 addresses specific details relating to procedures for the disposal of paper; metal; glass; plastic; organic waste and food scraps.
(2) Paper-this is divided and separated into two categories:-
contaminated non-recyclable paper waste (i.e. Newspapers/paper collected with plastics and food scraps) This is processed through the central waste system, baled and taken to the tip.
Uncontaminated recyclable paper waste (i.e. computer paper, reports etc)-processed through the CWS (on a special run) baled and sold to a contractor.
Metal-collected separately, placed into a special container at the loading dock and taken away for recycling by a contractor.
Glass-collected separately, placed into containers (brown, clear, green glass) at the loading dock and taken away for recycling by a contractor.
Plastic-processed with contaminated non-recyclable waste and taken to the tip.

Organic waste and food scraps-organic waste is taken to Mugga Lane recycling depot to be turned into compost. Wet food scraps are disposed of down the insinkerators and dry food scraps are deposited in the garbage compactor at the loading dock and taken to the tip.
